{{Infobox building |name = 461 Fifth Avenue |image = 461-5th-Bisanz.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = |location = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|NY]] |coordinates = {{coord|40.7523|-73.9815|region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} |status = |start_date = 1988 |completion_date = 1989 |est_completion = |opening = |building_type = Office and retail |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|376|ft|m|abbr=on}}<ref name='E'>{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=115200 |title=461 5th Avenue |accessdate=2009-06-20 |publisher=Emporis.com }}</ref> |top_floor = |floor_count = 28 |elevator_count = |cost = |floor_area = 200,000 square feet |architect = [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = [[Mitsui Fudosan]], [[London & New York Estates Corporation]], and [[Colonial Property Group]] |owner = [[SL Green Realty]] |management = |references = [http://461fifthavenue.info website] }} '''461 Fifth Avenue''' at 40th street is a 28-story [[skyscraper]] located in the [[Grand Central Terminal]] area of the [[Midtown Manhattan]] section of [[New York City]]. The building was constructed in 1988 by the [[Mitsui Fudosan]] development group and designed by [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]].<ref name='SSM'>{{cite web|url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=51412 |title=461 Fifth Avenue |accessdate=2009-06-20 |year=2009 |work=skyscraperpage.com |publisher=Skyscraper Source Media Inc | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629074143/http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=51412| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==History== In the late nineteenth century, 461 [[Fifth Avenue]] was the residence of the Misses Furniss, who were known for hosting musicals and other social functions.<ref name='NYT1895'>{{cite news | first= | last=Patriarch | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Society | date=1895-12-22 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1895/12/22/archives/society.html | work =New York Times | pages = 10 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629125943/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990CE6DB1E3DE433A25751C2A9649D94649ED7CF| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> They had acquired the address from a J. M. Bixby sometime after 1873.<ref name='NYT1873'>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=The Assessed Valuation.; The Work of the Supervisors' Committee Yesterday. | date=1873-07-31 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1873/07/31/archives/the-assessed-valuation-the-work-of-the-supervisors-committee.html | work =New York Times | pages =6 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629125938/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9906E4DE1239EF34BC4950DFB1668388669FDE| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Sometime between 1911 and 1915, the private house was replaced with an eleven-story office building, which in 1945 was renovated to become a [[Lane Bryant]] store.<ref name='NYT1911'>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Recent Demolition of Windsor Arcade Calls Attention to Fifth Avenue Changes | date=1911-06-18 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1911/06/18/archives/article-14-no-title.html | work =New York Times | pages =REFB-XX1 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = }}</ref><ref name='NYT1930'>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Silk House Takes Broadway Floor. | date=1930-05-02 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1930/05/02/archives/silk-house-takes-broadway-floor.html | work =New York Times | pages =RE-46 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = }} </ref><ref name='NYT1945'>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Store Alteration to Cost $200,000; Architects File Plans for New Home of Lane Bryant on Fifth Ave. | date=1945-11-08 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1945/11/08/archives/store-alteration-t0-cost-200000-architects-file-plans-for-new-home.html | work =New York Times | pages =B&F36 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629130443/http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40615FC3D5B10738DDDA10894D9415B8588F1D3| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> By 1988 the Lane Bryant building was demolished.<ref name='NYT1987'>{{cite news | first=Mark | last=McCain | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Real Estate; 8 Blocks Of 5th Ave. Awakening | date=1987-10-07 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/business/real-estate-8-blocks-of-5th-ave-awakening.html | work =New York Times | pages =D26 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629124307/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/business/real-estate-8-blocks-of-5th-ave-awakening.html| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The current structure was built in 1988 by a Japanese-lead development group using a design by [[Raul de Armas]] of [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]].<ref name='NYA'>{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc-architecture.com/MID/MID153.htm |title=461 Fifth Avenue Bldg |accessdate=2009-06-20 |last=Fletcher |first=Tom |work=nyc-architecture.com | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090606230720/http://www.nyc-architecture.com/MID/MID153.htm| archivedate= 6 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name='MB'>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecityreview.com/461fifth.html |title=461 Fifth Avenue |accessdate=2009-06-20 |last=Horsley |first=Carter B. |work=The Midtown Book |publisher=The City Review | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090626224451/http://thecityreview.com/461fifth.html| archivedate= 26 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Within a year of completion, the building had a 90% occupancy rate and had spurred a building boom in the Fifth Avenue area.<ref name='NYT1990'>{{cite news | first=Richard D. | last=Lyons | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Real Estate; A New Face For Stretch Of Fifth Ave. | date=1990-01-17 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/business/real-estate-a-new-face-for-stretch-of-fifth-ave.html | work =New York Times | pages =D22 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629124450/http://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/business/real-estate-a-new-face-for-stretch-of-fifth-ave.html| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> By 1992 it was fully leased.<ref name='EN'>{{cite web|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/13235454.html |title=461 5th Ave. 100% occupied with tenants such as the State Bank of South Australia. |accessdate=2009-06-20 |date=1992-12-02 |work=Real Estate Weekly |publisher=Hagedorn Publication }}</ref><ref name='NYT1988'>{{cite news | first=Mark | last=McCain | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Commercial Property: The Grand Central Area; Landlords Set Up a Special Tax to Upgrade District | date=1988-10-30 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/30/realestate/commercial-property-grand-central-area-landlords-set-up-special-tax-upgrade.html | work =New York Times | pages =10–37 | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629124444/http://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/30/realestate/commercial-property-grand-central-area-landlords-set-up-special-tax-upgrade.html| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The first floor shopping level was occupied by a [[Pier 1 Imports]] until 2007, when it was leased to [[BCBGMAXAZRIA]].<ref name='BC'>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-30066508_ITM |title=BCBG leases 14,000 s/f at 461 Fifth Avenue. |accessdate=2009-06-20 |date=2007-03-07 |work=Real Estate Weekly |publisher=Hagedorn Publication | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090629044526/http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-30066508_ITM| archivedate= 29 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The building was sold to its current owner, [[SL Green Realty]], in 2003 for $62.3 million.<ref name='AB'>{{cite news | first= | last=Real Estate Writers | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=SL Green Realty Corp. Announces Agreement to Acquire 461 Fifth Avenue for $62.3 Million. | date=2003-07-21 | publisher= | url =http://www.allbusiness.com/banking-finance/financial-markets-investing/5740383-1.html | work =Business Wire | pages = | accessdate = 2009-06-20 | language = | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090628181505/http://www.allbusiness.com/banking-finance/financial-markets-investing/5740383-1.html| archivedate= 28 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Architecture== The 461 Fifth Avenue building is noted for its use of modern materials, creating a stone-finish look, as well as its base-setback that is the same height as older buildings in the neighborhood. The building is also noted [[architecturally]] for its combination of a 10-story 19th-century base, which mirrors nearby older buildings, and an 18-story [[post-modern architecture|post-modern]] tower.<ref name='NYA'/><ref name='SL'>{{cite web |url=http://slgreen.com/properties/view/461-fifth-avenue |title=461 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, NY |accessdate=2009-06-20 |year=2009 |publisher=SL Green Realty Corp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628163751/http://slgreen.com/properties/view/461-fifth-avenue |archivedate=2009-06-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The exterior uses a [[pre-cast concrete]] finish to mimic the appearance of limestone and has a copper [[mansard]] roof similar to other buildings in the area.<ref name='MB'/><ref name='W'>{{cite web |url=http://461fifthavenue.info/main.cfm?sid=introduction&pid=about |title=About 461 Fifth Avenue |accessdate=2009-06-20 |year=2009 |publisher=Red Hand, L.L.C |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628165133/http://461fifthavenue.info/main.cfm?sid=introduction&pid=about |archivedate=2009-06-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=35em}}
[[Category:Skidmore, Owings & Merrill buildings]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1989]] [[Category:Postmodern architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Fifth Avenue]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox NYCS | name = 57 Street | wifi = yes | image = 6th Avenue - 57th Street - Platform.jpg | type = tempclosed | image_caption = | bg_color = #FF6E1A | address = West 57th Street & Sixth Avenue
New York, NY 10019 | borough = [[Manhattan]] | locale = [[Midtown Manhattan]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.764259|N|73.977213|W|display=inline,title}} | lat_dir = N | lon_dir = W | division = IND | line = [[IND Sixth Avenue Line]] | service = | service_custom = Closed | service_header = | connection = {{bus icon}} '''[[NYCT Bus]]''': {{NYC bus link|M5|M7|M31|M57}} | code = 224 | platforms = 1 [[island platform]] | tracks = 2 | structure = Underground | passengers = 4,557,372{{NYCS const|riderref}} | pass_year = 2017 | pass_percent = -5.5 | rank = 107 | open_date = {{start date and age|1968|07|01}} | close_date = {{start date and age|2018|07|09}} (reconstruction) | rebuilt = {{start date and age|2018|12}} | next_north = {{NYCS next | station=Lexington Avenue–63rd Street | line=63rd Street Lines | service=none}} | next_south = {{NYCS next | station=47th–50th Streets–Rockefeller Center | line=IND Sixth Avenue Line | service=none}} | legend = {{NYCS infobox legend|alltimes}} }} '''57th Street''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[IND Sixth Avenue Line]] of the [[New York City Subway]]. Located at the intersection of [[57th Street (Manhattan)|57th Street]] and [[Sixth Avenue]] (Avenue of the Americas) in [[Manhattan]], it is temporarily closed for renovations until December 2018. Under normal service patterns, it is served by the '''[[F (New York City Subway service)|F]]''' train at all times. North of the station, the line turns east and becomes the [[IND 63rd Street Line]]. First announced in 1962, the 57th Street station was opened on July 1, 1968, at the cost of $13.2 million. The station was a terminal station until 1989, after which all service was extended to [[21st Street–Queensbridge (IND 63rd Street Line)|21st Street–Queensbridge]]. The station was temporarily served by [[S (New York City Subway service)|shuttle trains]] in the 1990s during the [[63rd Street Lines|63rd Street Line's]] reconstruction. In July 2018, the station was closed for an extensive five-month renovation. ==History== {{stack|float=right| {{Routemap |title=Track layout |title-bg=#{{NYCS color|F}} |title-color=white |style=float:right;margin-top:5px;margin-left:10px; |legend =track |map= numN330\uvSTR!~MFADEg\ ~~ ~~ ~~ to [[Lexington Avenue–63rd Street (63rd Street Lines)|Lexington Av–63 St]] uvSTRfg uSHI1+l\uSHI1+r udSTR\exdBS\udSTR udSTR\exdBS\udSTR udSTR\exdBS\udSTR udSTR\exdBS\udSTR uSHI1l\uSHI1r uvÜST uvSTRfg uvSTR!~MFADEf ~~ ~~ ~~ to [[47th–50th Streets–Rockefeller Center (IND Sixth Avenue Line)|47–50 Sts]] }} }} The station was built as part of the [[Chrystie Street Connection]], which expanded train capacity on the Sixth Avenue Line. The Sixth Avenue extension to the new terminal at 57th Street was announced in 1962.{{Cite Routes Not Taken}} The next year, the contract to construct the IND Sixth Avenue Line between 52nd and 58th Streets, including the 57th Street station, was awarded to Slattery Construction Company for $7.5 million ({{Inflation|index=US|value=7500000|start_year=1962|r=-5|fmt=eq}}).{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1963/12/27/archives/ind-contract-awarded.html|title=IND Contract Awarded|date=December 27, 1963|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 18, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Construction of the spur ultimately cost $13.2 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1968/06/27/archives/luncheon-in-subway-opens-station.html|title=Luncheon in Subway Opens Station|date=June 27, 1968|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 18, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The 57th Street station opened on July 1, 1968, as one of two stations added during construction of the Chrystie Street Connection, the other being [[Grand Street (IND Sixth Avenue Line)|Grand Street]].{{cite web |last1=Perlmutter |first1=Emanuel |title=SUBWAY CHANGES TO SPEED SERVICE: Major Alterations in Maps, Routes and Signs Will Take Effect Nov. 26 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1967/11/16/90418352.pdf |website=[[The New York Times|nytimes.com]] |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=July 7, 2015 |date=November 16, 1967}} The opening of the station was celebrated by a 300-guest lunch on the platform on June 27, which was attended by Deputy Mayor [[Robert W. Sweet]]; MTA Chairman [[William J. Ronan]]; and Avenue of the Americas Association president Eyssell. The new station was intended to serve the new residential and commercial developments being built in the immediate area. Upon its opening, the 57th Street station acted as the [[terminal station|terminus]] of two services, the [[B (New York City Subway service)|B]] during rush hours and [[KK (New York City Subway service)|KK]] during off-peak hours.{{cite web |last1=Perlmutter |first1=Emanuel |title=BMT-IND CHANGES BEWILDER MANY; Transit Authority Swamped With Calls From Riders as New System Starts |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1967/11/27/archives/bmtind-changes-bewilder-many-transit-authority-swamped-with-calls.html |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=August 23, 2015 |date=November 27, 1967}} The KK was renamed the K in 1974 and eliminated in 1976.[http://nycsubway.org/perl/caption.pl?/img/maps/system_1972.jpg 1972 system map] ''NYCSubway'' Retrieved August 12, 2009{{cite web|last1=Burks|first1=Edward C.|title=215 More Daily Subway Runs Will Be Eliminated by Aug. 30|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1976/08/14/archives/215-more-daily-subway-runs-will-be-eliminated-by-aug-30-215-more.html|website=[[The New York Times|nytimes.com]]|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015|date=August 14, 1976}} From 1978 to 1990, this station was also served by the [[JFK Express]] service to the [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|eponymous airport]].{{Cite web|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/25/if-you-took-the-plane-to-the-train-sing-the-jingle/|title=If You Took the Train to the Plane, Sing the Jingle|last=Grynbaum|first=Michael M.|access-date=July 3, 2016|date=November 25, 2009}}{{cite news|title=New "JFK Express" Service Begun in Howard Beach|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/viewer/?file=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252023%2FForest%2520Parkway%2520NY%2520Leader%2520Observer%2FForest%2520Parkway%2520NY%2520Leader%2520Observer%25201978%2FForest%2520Parkway%2520NY%2520Leader%2520Observer%25201978%2520-%25200687.pdf&highlightsFile=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2Fhighlighter%2Fhits%2Ffbdb4829ac4f2348d1ab4d5338ab9a6c#page=1|accessdate=July 22, 2016|work=New York Leader Observer|agency=[[Fultonhistory.com]]|date=September 28, 1978}}{{cite news | first=David E. | last=Pitt | title=Transit Agency Wants to End Airport Express | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=October 22, 1989 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/22/nyregion/transit-agency-wants-to-end-airport-express.html | accessdate=May 13, 2009 }}{{cite web |title=Train to the Plane |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qkL1LIUsmqc |work=YouTube |accessdate=August 30, 2009}} When the north side of the Manhattan Bridge was closed for construction from 1986-1998 and again from July to December 2001, this station was only served by a [[S (New York City Subway service)|shuttle train]] along Sixth Avenue.[http://nycsubway.org/perl/caption.pl?/img/maps/system_1987.gif 1987 system map] ''NYCSubway'' Retrieved August 12, 2009 Starting in 1988, this station was served by [[Q (New York City Subway service)|Q]] trains on weekdays, B trains on weekday evenings and weekends, and [[F (New York City Subway service)|F]] trains during late nights. This was the terminal for all services until the IND 63rd Street Line to [[21st Street–Queensbridge (IND 63rd Street Line)|21st Street–Queensbridge]] opened on October 29, 1989{{cite news |title=The 'Subway to Nowhere' Now Goes Somewhere |first=Donatella |last=Lorch |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/29/nyregion/the-subway-to-nowhere-now-goes-somewhere.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 29, 1989 |accessdate=September 26, 2009}}{{cite news |title=V Train Begins Service Today, Giving Queens Commuters Another Option |first=Sarah |last=Kershaw |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/17/nyregion/v-train-begins-service-today-giving-queens-commuters-another-option.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 17, 2001 |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} Late night F-train service was replaced by a [[63rd Street Shuttle|shuttle]] in 1997. Since December 2001, when the 63rd Street Tunnel Connector opened in Queens, the F route has served this station at all times,{{cite web|title=Review of F Line Operations, Ridership, and Infrastructure|url=http://www.nysenate.gov/files/pdfs/flinereport_0.pdf|website=[[New York State Senate|nysenate.gov]]|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|MTA]] [[New York City Transit Authority]]|accessdate=July 28, 2015|date=October 7, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531101000/http://www.nysenate.gov/files/pdfs/flinereport_0.pdf|archivedate=May 31, 2010|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|title=Review of the G Line|url=http://web.mta.info/nyct/service/G_LineReview_7_10_13.pdf|website=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|mta.info]]|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|accessdate=August 2, 2015|date=July 10, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.subwaynut.com/brochures/63detour.htm |title=E,F Detour in 2001, F trains via 63 St, E no trains running, take R instead |work=The Subway Nut |accessdate=October 20, 2011}}{{Cite news|first=Randy |last=Kennedy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/25/nyregion/panel-approves-new-v-train-but-shortens-g-line-to-make-room.html |title=Panel Approves New V Train but Shortens G Line to Make Room |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 25, 2001 |accessdate=March 20, 2010}} simultaneous with the withdrawal of all other services from the 63rd Street Line. Under the 2015–2019 [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|MTA]] Capital Plan, this station, along with 32 others, will undergo a complete overhaul as part of the [[Enhanced Station Initiative]]. Updates would include cellular service, Wi-Fi, USB charging stations, interactive service advisories and maps, improved signage, and improved station lighting.{{cite web|url=http://gothamist.com/2016/01/08/subway_facelift_shutdown.php|title=MTA Will Completely Close 30 Subway Stations For Months-Long "Revamp"|publisher=Gothamist|accessdate=July 18, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160801200338/http://gothamist.com/2016/01/08/subway_facelift_shutdown.php|archivedate=August 1, 2016|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/MTAStations.pdf|title=MTAStations|last=|first=|date=|website=governor.ny.gov|publisher=Government of the State of New York|access-date=July 18, 2016}} In January 2018, the NYCT and Bus Committee recommended that Judlau Contracting receive the $125 million contract for the renovations of 57th and [[23rd Street (IND Sixth Avenue Line)|23rd Street]]s on the IND Sixth Avenue Line; [[28th Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|28th Street]] on the [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]], and 34th Street–Penn Station on the [[34th Street–Penn Station (IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line)|IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line]] and [[34th Street–Penn Station (IND Eighth Avenue Line)|IND Eighth Avenue Line]].{{Cite web|url=http://web.mta.info/mta/news/books/pdf/180122_1030_Transit.pdf|title=NYCT/Bus Committee Meeting|author=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|date=January 22, 2018|page=135|accessdate=January 19, 2018}} However, the MTA Board temporarily deferred the vote for these packages after city representatives refused to vote to award the contracts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.amny.com/transit/subway-station-improvements-1.16331101|title=Controversial cosmetic subway improvement plan falters|last=Barone|first=Vincent|date=January 24, 2018|work=am New York|access-date=2018-01-25|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/MTA-Postpones-Plan-Modernize-Subway-Stations-Cuomo-De-Blasio-470926353.html|title=MTA Shelves Plan to Modernize Subway Stations Amid Criticism|last=Siff|first=Andrew|date=January 24, 2018|work=NBC New York|access-date=2018-01-25|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} The contract was put back for a vote in February, where it was ultimately approved.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/mta-votes-cuomo-1b-plan-pretty-subway-stations-article-1.3836591|title=Foes Hit Gov's Station Fix Plan|date=2018-02-13|website=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-02-23}} The station was closed for renovations on July 9, 2018 until December 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mta.info/press-release/nyc-transit/repairs-and-improvements-coming-three-manhattan-6fm-subway-stations|title=Repairs and Improvements Coming to Three Manhattan 6FM Subway Stations|last=|first=|date=June 15, 2018|website=www.mta.info|publisher=Metropolitan Transportation Authority|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 18, 2018}} {{clear left}} == Station layout == {|table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=3 |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''G''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Street Level |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=500 valign=top|Exit/Entrance |- |'''M''' |Mezzanine |Fare control, station agent, MetroCard vending machines |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=50 rowspan=3 valign=top|'''P
Platform level''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100|'''Northbound''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=500|← {{rint|newyork|F}} does not stop here ([[Lexington Avenue–63rd Street (63rd Street Lines)|Lexington Avenue–63rd Street]]) |- |style="border-top:solid 2px black;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|{{small|[[Island platform]], temporarily closed for construction}} |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|'''Southbound''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|→ {{rint|newyork|F}} does not stop here ([[47th–50th Streets–Rockefeller Center (IND Sixth Avenue Line)|47th–50th Streets–Rockefeller Center]]) → |} [[File:IND F 57 sta jeh.jpg|thumb|left|Street entrance]] 57th Street contains two tracks and a single [[island platform]] serving both tracks.{{NYCS const|trackref|trackbook}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.subwaynut.com/ind/57f/index.php|title=57 Street (F)|publisher=The SubwayNut|last=Cox|first=Jeremiah|access-date=April 26, 2016}} From the full-length mezzanine, there are six staircases to the platform. The station walls are plain white, with "57th St" stenciled on long, narrow tiles along the wall.{{Cite AV media|url=http://www.subwaynut.com/ind/57f/57f6.jpg|title=57th Sts on the off white track walls|date=May 20, 2010|last=Cox|first=Jeremiah|type=image|language=|via=The Subway Nut}} The platform is approximately {{Convert|35|ft|m}} below ground. Much of the station design remains unchanged from 1968 opening. {{As of|2018}}, the "Next Train" indicator lights were still hanging from the platform ceiling, dating from the period when the station was a [[terminal station|terminal]] two decades prior.{{Cite AV media|url=http://www.subwaynut.com/ind/57f/57f12.jpg|title=A now unused Next Train indicator the first 21 years of the station it served as a terminal as well as when the 63 Street line had to be rebuilt due to the track bed having a faulty new design|date=May 20, 2010|last=Cox|first=Jeremiah|type=image|language=|via=The Subway Nut}} The tower and the crew area still exist. They were used until the 63rd Street extension opened to 21st Street–Queensbridge in 1989, but were back in service in 1998 when trains from Sixth Avenue terminated here due to long term construction work that necessitated a [[63rd Street Shuttle|shuttle train]] from Queensbridge to [[57th Street–Seventh Avenue (BMT Broadway Line)|57th Street–Seventh Avenue]] on the [[BMT Broadway Line]]. Once all construction work was completed on the 63rd Street Connector to the [[IND Queens Boulevard Line]] in December 2001, the tower was permanently abandoned.{{Cite AV media|url=http://www.subwaynut.com/ind/57f/57f13.jpg|title=At one end of the platform is an unused tower|date=May 20, 2010|last=Cox|first=Jeremiah|type=image|language=|via=The Subway Nut}} [[File:John T Oniell plaque 57 jeh.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|A plaque of Colonel John T. O'Neill is located in the station]] A plaque dedicated to retired Colonel John T. O'Neill, who served as the [[New York City Transit Authority]]'s Chief Engineer until his death in 1978, sits next to the booth on the west wall.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6WptAwAAQBAJ|title=The Underground Guide to New York City Subways|last=Frattini|first=Dave|date=April 1, 2000|publisher=Macmillan|year=|isbn=9780312253844|location=|pages=135|language=en|via=Google Books}} {{clear left}} ===Exits=== There are eight street staircases spread on both sides of Sixth Avenue from 56th to 57th Streets. These entrances have an unusual design, with lit posts reading "SUBWAY" on their side rather than the [[New York City Subway stations#Lamps|lighted red-or-green globes]] typical to other station entrances.{{Cite AV media|url=http://www.subwaynut.com/ind/57f/57f25.jpg|title=Old Subway text on the side of one of the posts on a street stair|date=May 20, 2010|last=Cox|first=Jeremiah|type=image|language=|via=The Subway Nut}} * One stair, NW corner of 6th Avenue and 57th Street{{cite web|title=MTA Neighborhood Maps: Midtown West|url=http://web.mta.info/maps/neighborhoods/mn/M10_midtown_west_2015.pdf|website=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|mta.info]]|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|accessdate=December 11, 2015|date=2015}} * One stair, NE corner of 6th Avenue and 57th Street * One stair, SW corner of 6th Avenue and 57th Street * Two stairs, east side of 6th Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets * One stair, NW corner of 6th Avenue and 56th Street * One stair, SW corner of 6th Avenue and 56th Street * One stair, SE corner of 6th Avenue and 56th Street {{clear left}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|57th Street (IND Sixth Avenue Line)}} * {{NYCS ref|http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/stations?221:306|IND 6th Avenue|57th Street}} * The Subway Nut – [http://www.subwaynut.com/ind/57f/index.php 57 Street] * Station Reporter — [https://web.archive.org/web/20120204051254/http://www.stationreporter.net/ftrain.htm F Train] * [https://maps.google.com/?ie=UTF8&layer=c&cbll=40.764028,-73.977422&panoid=X5TGhEgc2u8IJDBE3W4vaQ&cbp=12,147.48,,0,7.58&ll=40.764104,-73.977363&spn=0,0.009624&z=17 57th Street entrance from Google Maps Street View] * [https://maps.google.com/?ll=40.763406,-73.977867&spn=0.005241,0.009645&layer=c&cbll=40.763487,-73.977812&panoid=4nhMTq4OuzpGGwRSYWH_rQ&cbp=12,278.93,,0,8.05&t=m&z=17 56th Street entrance from Google Maps Street View] *[https://www.google.com/maps/contrib/103237729589375373179/photos/@40.7641907,-73.977272,3a,75y,72h,90t/data=!3m8!1e1!3m6!1s-yct2b6_DyNY%2FWULIs6wJ24I%2FAAAAAAAAshA%2FsLonJqr6K9k0SqF2O74PrFkimSvsQRTdwCLIBGAYYCw!2e4!3e11!6s%2F%2Flh3.googleusercontent.com%2F-yct2b6_DyNY%2FWULIs6wJ24I%2FAAAAAAAAshA%2FsLonJqr6K9k0SqF2O74PrFkimSvsQRTdwCLIBGAYYCw%2Fw203-h100-p-k-no%2F!7i8704!8i4352!4m3!8m2!3m1!1e1 Platform from Google Maps Street View] {{NYCS stations navbox by service|lf=y}} {{NYCS stations navbox by line|6ave=yes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:57th Street (Ind Sixth Avenue Line)}} [[Category:IND Sixth [[Image:AartKoopmans.jpg|thumb|Aart Koopmans|300px]]
'''Aart Koopmans''' (12 October 1946 – 15 January 2007) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] business man, president of the Dutch winter [[speed skating]] marathon organisation and founder of the [[Elfstedentocht|Alternative Elfstedentocht]]. His father, [[Bram Koopmans]] was the organiser for the [[Amstel Gold Race]] in [[road bicycle racing]] for many years.
Koopmans, born in [[Amsterdam]], organised his first Alternative Elfstedentocht in 1975 in [[Finland]] due to the winters in the Netherlands being too warm to skate 200 km in open air on ice. In later years, the Alternative Elfstedentochten were organised in various countries like [[Poland]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Canada]], [[Norway]], [[Sweden]] and [[Japan]]. In 2007 the first Alternative Elfstedentocht in [[Mongolia]] will be held.
The Austrian editions became the most popular through the years as thousands of Dutch people travel to the [[Weissensee (Carinthia)|Weissensee]] each year to compete each other in several speed skating marathons in various distances, with the 200 km Open Dutch National Championships being the main and most prestigious event. Until 2006 this gave the local authorities a profit of 36 million [[euro]]s. As a result, Koopmans and co-organiser [[Leo van Hees]] (who died in 2002) were awarded with the Austrian Cross of Honour.
Since 2006 he resided in [[Portugal]]. He was scheduled to retire from his position as Alternative Elfstedentocht organiser in 2011, but was taken to a [[Coimbra]] hospital in November 2006. He suffered from bacterial infections and [[pneumonia]], which resulted in his death on 15 January 2007.
The already scheduled Alternative Elfstedentocht of 2007 and the other scheduled races in the same period will go through, but in memorial of Aart Koopmans.
==References== *{{nl}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20070225115442/http://62.50.1.68/html/overlijdenaart.html Weissensee.nl report on his death] *{{nl}}[http://www.volkskrant.nl/sport/article388017.ece/Grondlegger_Alternatieve_Elfstedentocht_overleden?source=rss Volkskrant report on his death]
==External links==
{{commons category|Aart Koopmans}}

{{about|the Myanmar businessman|the Myanmar politician|Aung Ko (politician)}} {{Infobox person | name = Aung Ko Win | native_name = အောင်ကိုဝင်း | native_name_lang = my | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Burma]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Burmese | ethnicity = | occupation = Businessman | salary = | other_names = Saya Kyaung | known_for = | alma_mater = [[Mandalay University]] | spouse = Nang Than Htwe | children = Nang Lang Kham
Nang Kham Noung
Nang Mo Hom | parents = | awards = The Banker Awards (2013)
State Excellence Award (2013, 2014, 2015)
The Legacy Award (2017) | relatives = Zaw Win Naing (nephew) }} '''Aung Ko Win''' ({{lang-my|အောင်ကိုဝင်း}}; also known as '''Saya Kyaung''') is a Burmese businessman and former school teacher. He owns [[Kanbawza Group of Companies]] (KBZ), including [[Kanbawza Bank]], Myanmar Billion Group, Nilayoma Co. Limited, East Yoma Co. Limited and agent for London Cigarettes in Shan and Kayah States, and [[Kanbawza FC]]. ==Biography== He graduated "BSc in Chemistry" from [[Mandalay University]]. He is married to Nang Than Htwe,{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/ALL/?uri=uriserv:OJ.L_.2010.118.01.0010.01.ENG|title=Commission Regulation (EU) No 411/2010 of 10 May 2010 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 194/2008 renewing and strengthening the restrictive measures in respect of Burma/Myanmar |date=10 May 2010|work=Official Journal of the European Union|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=15 July 2015}} the niece of Win Myint, a former [[State Peace and Development Council]] official. He has 3 daughters, Nang Lang Kham (b. 1988), Nang Kham Noung (b. 1991), and Nang Mo Hom (b. 1996).{{cite web|url=https://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/F2007L04115|title=Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations 1959 - Direction Relating to Foreign Currency Transactions and to Burma (18/10/2007)|date=18 Oct 2007|work=Commonwealth of Australia|accessdate=15 July 2015}} His wife serves as Deputy Chairman of KBZ, while his three daughters serve as directors within the company.{{cite web|url=http://www.kbzgroup.com.mm/who_we_are |title=Our Board of Directors |work=KBZ Group |accessdate=15 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150716080757/http://www.kbzgroup.com.mm/who_we_are |archivedate=16 July 2015 |df= }} He has close connections to General [[Maung Aye]], the second in command of the former military junta, the [[State Peace and Development Council]] (SPDC){{cite web|url=http://www.ide.go.jp/English/Publish/Download/Brc/pdf/13_07.pdf|title=Business Conglomerates in the Context of Myanmar's Economic Reform|last=Aung Min|author2=Toshihiro Kudo|date=2014|work=Myanmar's Integration with Global Economy: Outlook and Opportunities|publisher=Bangkok Research Report|accessdate=11 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924032745/http://www.ide.go.jp/English/Publish/Download/Brc/pdf/13_07.pdf|archive-date=2015-09-24|dead-url=yes|df=}} While Maung Aye was a commander in [[jade]]-mining region of [[Shan State]], Maung Aye offered Aung Ko Win jade and gem mining concessions.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/13/us-myanmar-cronies-image-idUSBRE83B0YU20120413|title=Special Report: An image makeover for Myanmar Inc|last=Szep|first=Jason|date=13 April 2012|work=Reuters|accessdate=15 July 2015}} He is also chairman of the Myanmar Jades, Gems & Jewelry Entrepreneurs, Republic of The Union of Myanmar Federation of Chambers of Commerce & Industry (UMFCCI), [[Myanmar Football Federation]], Myanmar Anti-Narcotics Association and Border Area Development Association, Myanmar. ==Awards== Aung Ko Win was nominated as a "State Excellence Award" (2013, 2014, 2015) from the President of Myanmar for contributions to Myanmar and "Special Honorary State Excellence Award" 2014 and 2015 for the largest contribution to the Myanmar State Tax & Revenue Department and for community donations.{{cite web|url=http://www.kbzgroup.com.mm/who_we_are.html|title=Our Board of Directors for the KBZ Group of Companies is made up of the following members|work=KBZ Group|date=|accessdate=14 January 2018|language=en}} In 2015, Aung accepted "The Banker of the Year Award" in Asia 2015 award at a ceremony held at the London Stock Exchange on 3 December.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalnewlightofmyanmar.com/kbz-bank-wins-three-best-bank-awards-for-2015-from-world-finance/|title=KBZ Bank wins three best bank awards for 2015 from World Finance|work=Global New Light of Myanmar|date=9 December 2015|accessdate=14 January 2018|language=en}} In 2016, he gained "The Banker Awards" (2016) ceremony held at the Hilton London Bankside Hotel in London on 7 December. In 2017, he was awarded with the ASEAN’s "''The Legacy Award'' " conferred on him by the ASEAN Business Advisory Council-ABAC on 6 September in [[Manila]], Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalnewlightofmyanmar.com/asean-the-legacy-award-conferred-on-kbzs-chairman/|title=ASEAN "The Legacy Award" conferred on KBZ’s Chairman|work=Global New Light of Myanmar|date=8 September 2017|accessdate=14 January 2018|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Win, Aung Ko}} [[Category:Burmese businesspeople]]

{{Infobox building | name = Blue Shield of California Building | image = | caption = | former_names = Bechtel Building | location = 50 Beale Street
[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.7912|-122.3965|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco Central#California#USA | pushpin_label = Blue Shield Bldg. | completion_date = 1967 | building_type = Commercial offices | roof = {{convert|328|ft|abbr=on}} | floor_count = 23 | elevator_count = | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|730136|sqft|abbr=on}} | architect = [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] | structural_engineer= | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = Paramount Group, Inc. | management = | references = {{emporis|118861}}{{skyscraperpage|13247}} }} The '''Blue Shield of California Building''' is a {{convert|328|ft|abbr=on}}, 23-floor high-rise office building in the [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]] of [[San Francisco]], [[California]], located at 50 Beale Street between [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]] and [[Mission Street]]. Completed in 1967, the building serves as the world headquarters for the [[Bechtel|Bechtel Corporation]] with spill-over across the street to [[45 Fremont Center]]. The building has also served as headquarters for [[Blue Shield of California]] since 1996. In 2006, Blue Shield renewed its lease and acquired naming rights to the building. Formerly known as the '''Bechtel Building''', the building was renamed the Blue Shield of California Building. Broadway Partners acquired the building in 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2007/03/05/daily36.html |title=Broadway Real Estate buys South San Francisco building for $66 million |first=J.K. |last=Dineen |publisher=San Francisco Business Times |date=March 8, 2007}} A joint venture of The Rockefeller Group and Mitsubishi Estate New York acquired the building in September 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.cpexecutive.com/regions/west/rockefeller-jv-acquires-san-franciscos-50-beale-st/1004046558.html |title=Rockefeller JV Acquires San Francisco’s 50 Beale St. |date=September 14, 2012 |publisher=Commercial Property Executive}} The building was sold to Paramount Group, Inc. for approximately {{US$|395 million}} in September 2014.{{cite press release |url=http://news.theregistrysf.com/rockefeller-group-sells-50-beale-395mm/ |title=The Rockefeller Group Sells 50 Beale for $395MM |date=September 10, 2014 |publisher=The Registry}} ==Tenants== *[[Bechtel]]{{cite news |url=http://www.costar.com/News/Article/Bechtel-Renews-Office-Space-at-50-Beale/130255 |title=Bechtel Renews Office Space at 50 Beale |first=Dan |last=Bates |date=July 11, 2011 |publisher=CoStar}} *[[Blue Shield of California]]{{cite news |url=http://www.costar.com/News/Article/Blue-Shield-Inks-272000-SF-Lease-at-50-Beale/83154 |title=Blue Shield Inks 272,000-SF Lease at 50 Beale |first=Mike |last=Abdulkhaliq |date=October 3, 2006 |publisher=CoStar}}{{cite press release |url=https://www.blueshieldca.com/bsca/about-blue-shield/newsroom/blue-shield-building.sp |title=50 Beale Street to be Renamed Blue Shield of California Building |date=September 28, 2006 |publisher=Blue Shield of California}} *[[VerticalResponse]] ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco|San Francisco's tallest buildings]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140405135131/http://www.rockefellergroup.com/properties/50-beale-street-san-francisco/ 50 Beale Street - The Rockefeller Group] {{Buildings in San Francisco|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Financial District, San Francisco]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in San Francisco]] [[Category:Skidmore, Owings & Merrill buildings]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1967]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Dale Graham | image = | office1 = [[Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick]] | term_start1 = October 27, 2010 | term_end1 = October 25, 2014 | predecessor1 = [[Roy Boudreau]] | successor1 = [[Chris Collins (Canadian politician)|Chris Collins]] | office2 = [[Premier of New Brunswick|Deputy Premier of New Brunswick]] | term_start2 = June 21, 1999 | term_end2 = October 3, 2006 | premier2 = [[Bernard Lord]] | predecessor2 = [[Doug Tyler]] | successor2 = [[Donald Arseneault]] | office3 = [[Department of Human Resources (New Brunswick)|Minister of Human Resources]] | term_start3 = February 14, 2006 | term_end3 = October 3, 2006 | premier3 = [[Bernard Lord]] | predecessor3 = [[Rose-May Poirier]] | successor3 = [[Hédard Albert]] | office4 = [[Department of Government Services (New Brunswick)|Minister of Supply and Services]] | term_start4 = June 21, 1999 | term_end4 = February 14, 2006 | premier4 = [[Bernard Lord]] | predecessor4 = [[Greg O'Donnell]] | successor4 = [[Bev Harrison]] | office5 = Member of the
[[New Brunswick Legislative Assembly]]
for [[Carleton (1995–2014 New Brunswick provincial electoral district)|Carleton]] | term_start5 = September 11, 1995 | term_end5 = September 22, 2014 | predecessor5 = District created | successor5 = District abolished | office6 = Member of the
[[New Brunswick Legislative Assembly]]
for [[Carleton North]] | term_start6 = June 28, 1993 | term_end6 = September 11, 1995 | predecessor6 = [[Fred Harvey (politician)|Fred Harvey]] | successor6 = District abolished | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1951|10|6}} | birth_place = [[Woodstock, New Brunswick|Woodstock]], [[New Brunswick]] | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick|Progressive Conservative]] }} '''Dale Allison Graham''' (born October 6, 1951''Canadian Parliamentary Guide, 1997'', Kathryn O'Handley {{ISBN|1-896413-43-9}}) is a former [[politician]] in [[New Brunswick]], Canada. He served as an [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick|MLA]] from 1993 to 2014, as Speaker of the [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick]] from 2010 to 2014, and as a member of the [[Executive Council of New Brunswick|provincial cabinet]] from 1999 to 2006. Born in [[Woodstock, New Brunswick|Woodstock]], [[New Brunswick]], the son of Robert Graham and Letha Delong, Graham attended school in [[Centreville, New Brunswick|Centreville]]. He became a small business owner and was involved in local politics at the [[school board]] level. He married Shelley McDougall in 1972. In the [[New Brunswick general election, 1991|1991 provincial election]], Graham was defeated by [[New Brunswick Liberal Association|Liberal]] incumbent [[Fred Harvey (politician)|Fred Harvey]], however Harvey's victory was later declared void when Harvey was convicted of violating election spending laws. Graham was successful in a [[by-election]] in 1993 winning the [[Carleton North]] seat. Graham went on to be re-elected in the new [[electoral district]] of [[Carleton (1995-2014 New Brunswick provincial electoral district)|Carleton]] in the [[New Brunswick general election, 1995|1995]], [[New Brunswick general election, 1999|1999]], [[New Brunswick general election, 2003|2003]], [[New Brunswick general election, 2006|2006]] and [[New Brunswick general election, 2010|2010]] [[List of New Brunswick general elections (post-Confederation)|elections]]. Graham's 1993 victory was a key test for his [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick]]. His party had been defeated provincially in [[New Brunswick general election, 1987|1987]] going from having led the government for 17 years to being shut out of the legislature. Though the party regained 3 seats in the 58 seat legislature in 1991, the upstart [[Confederation of Regions Party of New Brunswick]] (CoR) had won 8 seats and claimed [[official opposition]]. Graham's victory was seen as a sign that CoR would not necessarily displace the Progressive Conservatives as the voice of [[conservatism]] in [[English Canadian|Anglophone]] New Brunswick. In 1999, Graham's party was returned to government. Graham, who co-chaired the election campaign, was named [[deputy premier]] and [[Department of Supply and Services (New Brunswick)|Minister of Supply and Services]]. On July 21, 2005, Graham added the responsibilities of [[Department of Environment and Local Government (New Brunswick)|Minister of Environment & Local Government]] on an acting basis when his cabinet colleague [[Brenda Fowlie]] was forced to resign from the cabinet. He retained the portfolio until November 21, 2005. In a [[cabinet shuffle]] on February 14, 2006, Graham was shuffled to the post of minister responsible for the [[Office of Human Resources (New Brunswick)|Office of Human Resources]] and for [[Service New Brunswick]]. He retained his honorary post of deputy premier. His party failed to win a plurality of seats in the 2006 election so Graham left cabinet and returned to opposition. He was re-elected in 2010 and his party returned to government, and he became [[Father of the House|dean of the legislature]]; he was excluded from cabinet but was elected to serve as speaker of the legislature. He did not seek re-election in 2014. == References == {{Reflist}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070902055451/http://www1.gnb.ca/legis/bios1/bio-e.asp?idNo=95&version=e MLA Bios, Government of New Brunswick] {{s-start}} {{s-non|reason=[[Roy Boudreau]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick]]|years=2010–2014}} {{s-non|reason=[[Chris Collins (Canadian politician)|Chris Collins]]}} {{s-break}} {{s-non|reason=''[[New Brunswick electoral redistribution, 1994|new district]]''}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick|MLA]] for [[Carleton (1995-2014 New Brunswick provincial electoral district)|Carleton]]|years=1995–2014}} {{s-non|reason=''[[New Brunswick electoral redistribution, 2013|district abolished]]''}} {{s-break}} {{s-vac|last=[[Fred Harvey (politician)|Fred Harvey]]
([[New Brunswick Liberal Association|Liberal]])}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick|MLA]] for [[Carleton North]]|years=1993–1995}} {{s-non|reason=''[[New Brunswick electoral redistribution, 1994|district abolished]]''}} {{s-end}} {{s-start}} {{Canadian cabinet member navigational box header |ministry=Bernard_Lord}} {{ministry box cabinet posts | post3 = [[Office of Human Resources (New Brunswick)|Minister of Human Resources]] | post3years = 2006 | post3note = | post3preceded = [[Rose-May Poirier]] | post3followed = [[Hédard Albert]] | post2 = [[Department of Supply and Services (New Brunswick)|Minister of Supply and Services]] | post2years = 1999–2006 | post2note = | post2preceded = [[Greg O'Donnell]] | post2followed = [[Bev Harrison]] | post1 = [[Department of Environment and Local Government (New Brunswick)|Minister of Environment and Local Government]] (acting) | post1years = 2005 | post1note = | post1preceded = [[Brenda Fowlie]] | post1followed = [[Trevor Holder]] }} {{ministry box special cabinet | post2 = [[Deputy Premier]] of [[New Brunswick]] | post2years = 1999–2006 | post2note = Deputy Premier was not included in the next cabinet | post2preceded = [[Doug Tyler]] | post2followed = [[Donald Arseneault]] | post1 = Minister responsible for [[Service New Brunswick]] | post1years = 2006 | post1note = | post1preceded = [[Percy Mockler]] | post1followed = [[Greg Byrne]] }} {{s-end}} {{Lord Ministry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Graham, Dale}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian Baptists]] [[Category:Deputy premiers of New Brunswick]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick MLAs]] [[Category:Members of the Executive Council of New Brunswick]] [[Category:People from Woodstock, New Brunswick]] [[Category:21st-century Canadian politicians]]

{{Other uses|Dave Chalk}} {{Infobox person | name = David Chalk | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1963|9}} | birth_name = David Ian Chalk | birth_place = [[Croydon]], England {{flagicon|England}} | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | occupation = Entrepreneur, media personality | website = {{URL|www.askdavechalk.com}}
{{URL|http://chalk.today/}}}} '''David Ian Chalk''' (born 1963) is a Canadian technology entrepreneur and media personality who hosted the syndicated ''Dave Chalk's Computer Show'',[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304120353/http://www.locatetv.com/tv/dave-chalks-computer-show/1571820 "Dave Chalk's Computer Show," LocateTV website] and its subsequent incarnations ''Dave Chalk Computer Life'',[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304201100/http://www.locatetv.com/tv/dave-chalks-computer-life/1789067 "Dave Chalk's Computer Life", LocateTV website] ''Dave Chalk Connected Live'',[http://www.prweb.com/releases/2003/11/prweb89400.htm "Dave Chalk Returns to National Television with New 'Live and Interactive' Technology Show", PRWeb website] ''Dave Chalk Connected'',[http://www.globeinvestor.com/servlet/WireFeedRedirect?cf=GlobeInvestor/config&vg=BigAdVariableGenerator&date=20040922&archive=cnw&slug=1209222327 "Chalk Media Corp. CEO update Letter to Shareholders", The Globe and Mail website, Globe Investor section] and ''Dave Chalk Connected (In-flight)''.[http://www.adnews.com/19255 "TELUS to Sponsor Dave Chalk Connected", AdNews website] == Early life == Chalk was born in [[Croydon]], [[England]] on September 1963 and relocated with his family to [[British Columbia]], Canada. As a youth he suffered from [[Dyslexia]],{{cite web |url= http://www.thepowerofdyslexia.com/famous-dyslexics/ |title=Famous People With Dyslexia | Famous Dyslexics | |first= |last= |work=thepowerofdyslexia.com |year=2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} [[prosopagnosia|face blindness]] and other afflictions he acquired from brain damage at birth.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110826083452/http://rogerbjones.com/index.php?page=a-profile-of-david-chalk Interview with Roger B. Jones, June 7, 2010] == Education == Chalk completed high school, but did not finish his university degree. Chalk was granted an Honorary Doctorate of Technology by the [[University of the Fraser Valley]]’s Alumni Association board."[https://web.archive.org/web/20120323110630/http://www.ufv.ca/MarCom/newsroom/Chalk.htm "Honorary degree: David Chalk", University of Fraser Valley website, June 13, 2006.] == Career highlights == Chalk established the longest-running technology show in Canada ("Dave Chalk's Computer Show"),[https://web.archive.org/web/20120801165756/http://www.microsoft.com/business/smb/en-ca/smallbiz/products/customermanagement/articles/who_is_dave_chalk.mspx "Who is Dave Chalk?", by Dave Chalk, Microsoft SME Business Centre, date unknown] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chalk, David}} [[Category:Canadian television hosts]] [[Category:Canadian radio personalities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Croydon]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:BlackBerry Limited people]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:People diagnosed with dyslexia]] [[Category:People with prosopagnosia]]

revision.text:
'''Earnings''' are the net benefits of a [[corporation]]'s operation.<ref>Robert G. Eccles, Robert H. Herz, E. Mary Keegan, David M. H. Phillips: The Value Reporting Revolution: Moving Beyond the Earnings Game; Price-Waterhouse-Coopers, 2001.</ref> Earnings is also the amount on which corporate [[tax]] is due. For an analysis of specific aspects of corporate operations several more specific terms are used as [[Earnings before interest and taxes|EBIT]] -- earnings before interest and taxes, [[EBITDA]] - earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization.
Many alternative terms for earnings are in common use, such as [[income]] and [[Profit (accounting)|profit]]. These terms in turn have a variety of definitions, depending on their context and the objectives of the authors. For instance, the [[IRS]] uses the term profit to describe earnings, whereas for the corporation the profit it [[form 10-K|report]]s is the amount left after [[tax]]es are taken out. Many economic discussions use principles derived from [[Karl Marx]] <ref>Karl Marx: Das Kapital, Kritik der Politischen Oekonmie; 1967.</ref> and [[Adam Smith]].<ref>Adam Smith: The Wealth of Nations; 1876.</ref> However the rise of the importance of [[intellectual capital]] <ref>Gordon Smith and Russell Parr: Intellectual Property, 4th edition; Wiley 2005.</ref> affects such analyses.
==Routine earnings== Routine earnings or [[commodity]]-based earnings are those that can be achieved by application of assets that are those that can be achieved by any business that employs sufficient [[capital (economics)|capital]] and manpower. These conditions are commonly assumed in economic analyses of [[profit (economics)]]
==Non-routine earnings== The use of [[intellectual property]] generates non-routine profits. Those are often an order-of-magnitude greater than routine earnings.<ref>John Hand and Baruch Lev (editors): Intangible Assets, Values, Measures. and Risks; Oxford University Press, 2003.</ref> Non-routine profits are essential to warrant the high [[investment]]s needed for [[high-technology]] industries.
== Earnings manipulation == Some statistical models (e.g. based on [[Benford's law]] or [[Beneish M-Score]]) are used in order to detect possible earnings manipulations (fraud).
==Citations== <references/>
[[Category:Business terms]]

{{About|the general occupation|the occupation in several armed forces|Electronics technician (armed forces)|the US naval rating|Electronics technician (United States Navy)}} '''Electronics technicians''' help design, develop, test, manufacture, install, and repair electrical and [[electronic equipment]] such as communication equipment, medical monitoring devices, navigational equipment, and [[computers]]. They may be employed in product evaluation and testing, using measuring and diagnostic devices to adjust, test, and repair equipment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opm.gov/qualifications/standards/IORs/gs0800/0856.htm |title=Electronics Technical Series |publisher=Opm.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref> Electronics technicians may also work as sales workers or field representatives for manufacturers, wholesalers, or retailers giving advice on the installation, operation, and maintenance of complex equipment and may write specifications and technical manuals. Electronics technicians represent over 33% of all engineering technicians in the U.S. In 2009, there were over 160,000 electronics technicians employed in the U.S.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/oco/ocos112.htm |title=Architecture and Engineering Occupations : Occupational Outlook Handbook : U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics |publisher=Bls.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref> Electronics technicians are accredited by organizations such as the [[Electronics Technicians Association]] (ETA), or International Society of Certified Electronics Technicians (ISCET).
==Education and training== Most employers prefer to hire electronics technicians with an associate degree or other post-secondary training in [[engineering technology]]. Training is available at [[technical institute]]s, at [[community colleges]], at extension divisions of colleges and [[universities]], at public and private vocational-technical schools, and in the [[Armed Forces]]. Naval electronics technicians are the largest group of engineering technicians in the military (see [[Electronics Technician (US Navy)]]). Many 2-year associate degree programs accredited by the Technology Accreditation Commission of the [[Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology]] (ABET) include at least college algebra and trigonometry and one or two basic science courses. Depending on the specialty, more math or science may be required. About 200 ABET-accredited programs are offered in engineering technology specialities.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> ABET-accredited electronics technician programs usually require at least two mathematics courses and two physics courses in addition to the core competencies.
Electronics technician curriculum generally consists of courses in basic electricity and electronics, including [[Ohm's Law]], Parallel and Series Circuits, [[Magnetism]], AC/DC Circuits, [[Capacitance]], [[Inductance]], [[Transformer]]s, [[Resonance]], [[Filter (signal processing)|Filters]], [[Semiconductors]], [[Transistors]], [[Amplifiers]], [[Integrated Circuits]] and [[Digital electronics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=ED396157&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=ED396157 |title=Raising the Standard. Electronics Technician Skills for Today and Tomorrow |publisher=Eric.ed.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref> In addition to vocational learning outcomes associated with the study of electronics and control systems, graduates of electronics technician programs are also expected to have essential employability skills and meet certain general education learning outcomes. Individual schools largely determine the specific program structure, delivery methods, and other curriculum components to be used to assist students in achieving the required program outcomes.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185126/http://www.tcu.gov.on.ca/eng/general/college/progstan/techno/55203e.pdf ]</ref>
A significant component of course material includes laboratory experimentation. These lab courses and projects often represent up to 50% of the course material and are used to reinforce theoretical concepts associated with the study of electronics. Schools offering electronics technician programs will have electronics laboratories to support the delivery of course curriculum. Historically, these laboratories have been traditional "hands on" learning environments, although in recent years the trend is moving towards [[electronics simulation]] software such as [[Multisim]] and [[CircuitLogix]]. Electronics software simulation is also used in conjunction with traditional labs to provide greater opportunities for students to complete laboratory projects as part of their studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://courseweb.xu.edu.ph/courses/files/Electronics%20Workbench%20News%20No_%208.htm |title=Electronics Workbench News No. 8 |publisher=Courseweb.xu.edu.ph |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref>
==Career prospects== The demand for jobs in the electronics engineering and service fields is the result of a recent proliferation of both consumer and industrial electronics products. The design, installation, servicing and maintenance of this equipment has created significant employment opportunities in the electronics industry.<ref>[http://www.tcu.gov.on.ca/eng/ojf/pdf/2242_e.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100119155558/http://www.tcu.gov.on.ca/eng/ojf/pdf/2242_e.pdf |date=January 19, 2010 }}</ref>
Typical job-related activities may involve:
* assembly * installation * [[Maintenance, repair and operations|maintenance]] * testing * [[troubleshooting]] * repair * upgrading of associated electronic equipment and systems.
Job opportunities for electrical and electronics technologists and technicians are increasing because many industries use electronic products and systems. Key sectors are [[telecommunications]], audio/video, computers, [[robotics]], [[energy conversion]] and efficiency, [[power generation]], transmission and distribution, and electrical equipment manufacturing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.settlement.org/alternativejobs/career.aspx?j=21 |title=Alternative Jobs |publisher=Settlement.org |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref> Employment opportunities for electronics technicians vary and are largely based on their areas of expertise. For example, employment growth for Electronics technicians in areas such as robotics, energy conversion, and power generation is expected to grow by 5%/yr from 2010 through 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/oco/ocos184.htm#outlook |title=Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers : Occupational Outlook Handbook : U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics |publisher=Bls.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
