{{Infobox company | name=Firestone Natural Rubber Company, LLC | logo= | type=[[Subsidiary]] | industry=[[Rubber]] | founded= | location=[[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people=Ed Garcia <small>([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]])</small> | owner=[[Bridgestone Americas, Inc]] | homepage=[http://www.firestonenaturalrubber.com/ Firestonenaturalrubber.com] }} '''Firestone Natural Rubber Company, LLC''' is a subsidiary of the [[Bridgestone| Bridgestone Americas, Inc]]. Headquartered in [[Nashville, TN]], the company operates the largest contiguous rubber plantation in the world in [[Liberia]], which first opened in 1926.
==History==
===Creation and early history=== During the 1920s, the United States access to [[rubber]] was restricted by the European colonial powers (Britain and the Netherlands), which held a monopoly in rubber production.<ref name="AfrDict">Robert Anthony Waters Jr, ''Historical Dictionary of United States-Africa Relations'', Scarecrow Press, 2009, {{ISBN|9780810862913}}, p. 103-104</ref> [[Herbert Hoover]], then Secretary of Commerce, considered rubber a vital resource due to its usage for car tires and began working with American rubber companies in order to find a rubber source that was controlled by US interests.<ref name="AfrDict"/> Part of a Department of Commerce-subsidised worldwide search for a place for rubber plantations, rubber magnate [[Harvey Samuel Firestone]] sent experts to Liberia in December 1923 to do a soil survey.<ref name="AfrDict"/>
In 1926, the Liberian government granted Firestone a 99-year lease for a million acres (to be chosen by the company wherever in Liberia) at a price of 6 cents per acre,<ref name="dubois">W. E. Burghardt Du Bois, "[http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/69368/w-e-burghardt-du-bois/liberia-the-league-and-the-united-states Liberia, the League and the United States]", ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'', July 1931</ref> Firestone then set about establishing rubber tree plantations of the non-native South American rubber tree, [[Hevea brasiliensis]] in the country, eventually creating the world's largest rubber plantation.<ref name="AfrDict"/> Firestone also provided a $5 million loan at a 7% interest rate<ref name="dubois"/> to the government to pay the foreign debts it had <ref name="AfrDict"/> and to build a harbour needed by Firestone.<ref name="dubois"/> The loan was given in exchange for complete authority over the government's revenues until the loan was paid.<ref>Rosenau, p. 17</ref>
The loan took a larger and larger portion of the Liberian government's incomes: it grew from 20% of the total revenue of Liberia in 1929, to 32% in 1930, to 54.9% in 1931 and nearly the whole revenue in 1932.<ref name="dubois"/> An estimation made by a member of the American Legation in Liberia said that Liberia really paid a 17% interest rate for the loan.<ref name="dubois"/>
During the [[Great Depression]], as rubber price fell,<ref name="dubois"/> Firestone stopped its development of the plantation (using just 50,000 acres and cutting wages in half), and, depriving the Liberian government of tax incomes, the government missed a payment to the loans to the company. Firestone asked the US government to send a warship to [[Monrovia]] to enforce the debt payment, but President [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]] rejected the "gunboat diplomacy".<ref name="AfrDict"/> The loans to the company were finally paid in 1952.<ref>Rosenau, p. 18</ref>
===During the civil wars=== As rubber demand went down during the 1980s, Firestone dismissed a number of 5000 workers, leading to the local antipathy to the company.<ref name="Rosenau20">Rosenau, p. 20</ref> On June 6, 1990, during the [[First Liberian Civil War]], the resistance group [[National Patriotic Front of Liberia]] took over the Firestone plantation and evacuated US personnel.<ref name="Rosenau20"/> The exact nature of Firestone's activities in the plantation between 1990 and 1997 is unclear, the government's official stance was that they were able to take it back within a few months,<ref name="Rosenau20"/> while media reports say that it was not operational until late 1994.<ref name="Rosenau21">Rosenau, p. 21</ref>
In 1997, after the violence was over, the company restarted the operations, at first at a third of capacity, with 3000 workers.<ref name="Rosenau21"/> The company soon faced a number of violent protests, as its employees wanted better working conditions, better pay and resettlement benefits.<ref name="Rosenau21"/> By October 2008, it was operating at half the capacity, withholding further investments until the government finally agreed to give the company a lenient tax status.<ref name="Rosenau22">Rosenau, p. 22</ref>
===Current operations===
In 2005, the Firestone Company and the Liberian government signed a new 37-year deal raising the lease to 50 cents per acre.<ref name="AfrDict"/>
==Labor controversy== The workers accuse the company of serious labor abuses, including exploitative [[child labor]], which they claim amount to modern-day [[slavery]].<ref name="UNMIL Rubber, indicated pages"/> Workers specifically claim that Firestone's high daily quotas force them to employ their own children, subjecting them to grueling and dangerous work conditions. In response to the claims, the president of Firestone Natural Rubber told a [[CNN]] interviewer that "each tapper will tap about 650 trees a day, where they spend perhaps a couple of minutes at each tree." As the network pointed out, this would add up to more than 21 hours of work per day.<ref name="CNN">{{cite web | title =Is Bridgestone/Firestone Exploiting Liberian Workers? | publisher=CNN| url =http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0511/12/i_if.01.html }}</ref>
In May 2006, the [[United Nations Mission in Liberia]] (UNMIL) released a report detailing the state of [[human rights]] on Liberia's rubber plantations.<ref name="UNMIL Rubber, indicated pages"/> According to the report, Firestone managers in Liberia admitted that the company does not effectively monitor its own policy prohibiting child labor. UNMIL found that several factors contribute to the occurrence of child labor on Firestone plantations: pressure to meet company quotas, incentive to support the family financially, and lack of access to basic education.<ref name="UNMIL Rubber, indicated pages"/>
===Alien Tort Claims Act=== In November 2005, the [[International Labor Rights Fund]], representing "tappers" (workers who extract [[latex]] from [[Hevea brasiliensis|rubber trees]]) on the Liberian plantation, filed an [[Alien Tort Statute|Alien Tort Claims Act]] (ATCA) case in US District Court in California against [[Bridgestone]] (parent company owning Firestone), alleging "forced labor, the modern equivalent of slavery", on the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company|Firestone]] Plantation in [[Harbel]], [[Liberia]].<ref name="Claim against Firestone">{{cite web|title=Firestone Claim|work=socialfunds.com|url=http://www.socialfunds.com/news/article.cgi/1897.html}}</ref>
The lawsuit stated: {{cquote|The Plantation workers allege, among other things, that they remain trapped by poverty and coercion on a frozen-in-time Plantation operated by Firestone in a manner identical to how the Plantation was operated when it was first opened by Firestone in 1926.}}
Firestone rejected these allegations, stating that the corporation has provided employment and pensions to thousands of Liberians as well as healthcare. The company also provides education and training opportunities to employees and their children.<ref name = "Firestone Briefing">{{cite web|title =Firestone Briefing|work =lantos.house.org|url =http://lantos.house.gov/HoR/CA12/Human+Rights+Caucus/HRC+Hidden+Content/12-09-05+Liberia+and+Firestone+Briefing.htm}}</ref>
In reply to the charge of exploitative [[child labor]], Management of the plantation claims that workers are bringing their own children to work to assist them and that this is not endorsed by the plantation management.
Workers claim that management's high daily quotas force them to employ their own children as their only means of meeting quotas.
Even though Liberia does have child labor laws and Firestone has banned children from tapping trees, workers say the ban is not enforced. The workers say the only way they can complete their daily quota is to bring their children along.
Firestone management says if children are found helping their parents, the employees are cancelled, and if necessary, disciplined. "We have very strict policies about our child labor. We do not hire anybody under 18 years of age, and we discourage parents from bringing their children to the fields with them."<ref name = "CNNtranscript">{{cite web | title =Liberian Controversy | work =cnn.com | url =http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0511/12/i_if.01.html | accessdate=2006-07-30 }}</ref>
Firestone requested to transfer the case to [[Indianapolis, Indiana|Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], from California and this request was granted in April 2006.
===UN report=== In May 2006, the [[United Nations Mission in Liberia]] (UNMIL) released a report: "Human Rights in Liberia’s Rubber Plantations: Tapping into the Future".<ref name="UNMIL Rubber, indicated pages">{{cite web|title=Human Rights in Liberia's Rubber Plantations: Tapping into the Future|publisher=United Nations Mission in Liberia (2006)|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/473dade10.html|accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref>
According to the report, Firestone managers in Liberia admitted that the company does not effectively monitor its own policy prohibiting child labor. UNMIL found that several factors contribute to the occurrence of child labor on Firestone plantations: pressure to meet company quotas, incentive to support the family financially, and lack of access to basic education. The report also noted that workers' housing provided by Firestone has not been renovated since the houses were constructed in the 1920s and 1930s.<ref name="UNMIL Rubber, indicated pages"/>
In response to the accusations of [[child labor]] and poor housing in the UN report, Dan Adomitis, President of Firestone Natural Rubber Company Liberia, stated: {{cquote| Well, in addition to the devastation that 15 years of civil war has caused, I think you need to understand another point—during the 2003 fighting, we had thousands of refugees come to Harbel for the safety that it provided. When those people came, they occupied any open area of land that was available. They put up temporary housing made out of mud, out of bamboo, out of thatch, out of tarpaulin, out of corrugated steel. Anything that they could do to get shelter. And those conditions still exist. They are not Firestone housing, but they are on our property.<ref name = "CNN"/>...
We have very strict policies about child labor. We do not hire anybody under 18 years of age, and we discourage parents from bringing their children to the fields with them. We have a program with the Ministry of Labor in Liberia to - and also the union that represents our employees—to educate parents about why they should not bring children with them into the field. And if we see incidents of this, we will cancel those employees, and if necessary, ultimately discipline them over such issue.<ref name="CNNtranscript"/>}}
==See also== *[[Corporate abuse]] *[[Crisis management]] *[[Wage slavery]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * William Rosenau, ''Corporations and Counterinsurgency'', [[Rand Corporation]], 2009, {{ISBN|9780833047519}}
==External links== *[http://www.firestonenaturalrubber.com/ Official site] *[http://www.laborrights.org/press/Firestone/allafrica_112105.htm Firestone Mired in Slave Labor Charges in Liberia] *[http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=31444 Rubber Workers Charge Slave-Like Conditions] *[http://www.stopfirestone.org Child labor, Exploitation, Environmental Destruction] – Stop Firestone Coalition; retrieved on 2008-08-02
[[Category:Business ethics cases]] [[Category:Child labour]] [[Category:Companies of Liberia]]

[[Image:FFountainJax2011.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The newly renovated Friendship Fountain in 2011]] '''Friendship Fountain''' is a large [[fountain]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. It is in '''St. Johns River Park''' (also known as '''Friendship Fountain Park''') at the west end of [[Downtown Jacksonville]]'s [[Jacksonville Riverwalk|Southbank Riverwalk]] attraction. The world's largest and tallest fountain when it opened, it has been one of Jacksonville's most recognizable and popular attractions.<ref>[http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/050606/ner_21783751.shtml Florida Times-Union: May 6, 2006-Fountain feedback]</ref><ref>Scanlan, Dan: [http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/032801/ner_5741309.shtml "Fountain goes dry for repairs"] Florida Times-Union, March 28, 2001</ref>
The fountain and park were designed by Jacksonville architect [[Taylor Hardwick]] in 1963 and opened in 1965. The fountain's three pumps could push {{convert|17,000|USgal|L}} of water per minute up to {{convert|100|feet|meters}} in height. Friendship Fountain remained one of Jacksonville's signature attractions through the 20th century, but severe corrosion and deterioration to the equipment resulted in periodic closures in the 2000s. In 2011 the city completed a $3.2 million renovation to the fountain and the surrounding park.
==History== {{Refimprove section|date=February 2009}} [[Image:FriendshipFountainParkPC.JPG|left|thumb|250px|The original Friendship Fountain & Park]] The fountain and Friendship Park was designed by [[Taylor Hardwick]], the Jacksonville architect who also designed the [[Haydon Burns Library]]. An area of {{convert|14|acre|m2}} of land were donated for the project by the Southside Business Men's Club, an organization dedicated to the improvement of the Southside that was established in 1932.<ref name="taylorhardwick.com">[http://www.taylorhardwick.com/ Taylor Hardwick, AIA]</ref>{{Verify credibility|date=February 2009}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Southside Business Men's Club|url=http://www.southsidebusinessmensclub.com/|publisher=Southside Business Men's Club|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> Begun in 1963 and completed at a cost of $1.7 million,<ref name=TU/> the park opened in March 1965. The "world’s largest and tallest" fountain at the time, it became a popular tourist attraction.<ref>[http://apps2.coj.net/parksinternet/parkdetails.asp?parkid=227 "Friendship Fountain"] City of Jacksonville website, Recreation & Community Service</ref>
The three pumps had a combined {{convert|750|hp}} and could push {{convert|17,000|USgal|L}} per minute; some streams as tall as a 10-story building. The enclosure for the pumps and controls was so large that the architect had to include it as an element of design.<ref name="taylorhardwick.com"/>{{Verify credibility|date=February 2009}}
The Fountain was originally called the "Fountain of Friendship in Dallas Thomas Park"; ''friendship'' at the suggestion of a [[Rotary International|Rotary Club]] member and ''Dallas Thomas'' after the city's parks and finance commissioner. However, when Thomas was later involved in a scandal and indicted, the park was renamed in 1968.<ref>[http://www.jaxfountain.com/Original/history.htm Friends of the Friendship Fountain website: History]</ref>
===Harbormasters and River City Brewing Company=== The [[Acosta Bridge]] was rebuilt beginning in 1990, and the Diamond Head Lobster House was in its path and had to be demolished. The city agreed to use a big portion of Friendship park for the new restaurant and parking lot, cutting the park by more than half.<ref name="taylorhardwick.com"/>{{Verify credibility|date=February 2009}}<ref name=HIST>{{cite web|title=Friendship Fountain History|url=http://apps2.coj.net/parksinternet/parkdetails.asp?parkid=227|publisher=City of Jacksonville|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> Essentially, all the design structures in the park were removed-—with the exception of the fountain itself—-for what became a [[Boondoggle (project)|boondoggle]]. The new facility was named Harbormasters, and the city guaranteed a $2.9 million federal building loan on the city's land. Initial success was followed by lawsuits, a new owner, missed rent payments, foreclosure, loan default and finally closure in 1992.<ref name=DEAL>{{cite news|last=Littlepage|first=Ron|title=After 3 failures, will Jacksonville spurn more restaurant deals?|url=http://members.jacksonville.com/opinion/premium/401979/ron-littlepage/2013-01-20/ron-littlepage-after-3-failures-will-jacksonville|accessdate=21 January 2013|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=January 20, 2013}}</ref> When the venture failed, the city had to pay off the nearly $3 million loan. The River City Brewing Company, which replaced Harbormasters in November 1993, has been successful, but because the city owns the land, the restaurant pays no property taxes.<ref name=FAILS>{{cite news|last=Saunders|first=Jim|title=Development plan fails|url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/071197/HARBORMA.html|accessdate=17 September 2012|newspaper=Florida Times-Union|date=July 11, 1997}}</ref>
[[Image:Friendship Fountain at Night Panorama.jpg|300px|right|thumb|The fountain at night running on one pump.]]
===Long service=== Friendship Fountain functioned for over 20 years and was refurbished in December 1985, before resuming operation for another 15 years. Finally, wear and corrosion forced its closure at the end of the century. A five-month, $1.3 million rehabilitation began when the fountain was drained in March 2001. A new feature was added: six light towers with computer-controlled color-changing floodlights. Unanticipated damage to stainless steel pipes was uncovered, requiring a $97,000 increase in cost and two-month delay, but the fountain re-opened in December 2001.<ref name=TU/><ref>Scanlan, Dan: [http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/083001/met_7149653.html "Friendship Fountain high 'n' dry Landmark to spout in early October"] Florida Times-Union, August 30, 2001</ref> It operated for seven months until a power outage/[[voltage spike]] damaged the computer controller and blew out 40 lights and lenses on April 29, 2002. That was repaired, and the fountain was fully functional for nearly 3 years. It was a major attraction at [[Super Bowl XXXIX]] in February 2005, but two months later, two of the three original (40-year-old) pumps failed and parts were no longer available. The replacement cost for the pumps was estimated at $400,000, but the city budget was tight and money was not available. Afterward the fountain was run on one pump with a greatly reduced flow.<ref name=TU>Scanlan, Dan: [http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/061505/ner_18989533.shtml "Friendship Fountain's water jets falter due to bad pumps"] Florida Times-Union, June 15, 2005</ref> It was repaired in 2011 and is functional.
==Features== *The fountain’s basin is {{convert|200|ft|m}} in diameter holding {{convert|500,000|USgal|L}} of water which is treated according to [[swimming pool sanitation]] standards. *The spray component consists of three rings. *The outer ring contains 36 nozzles, equally spaced around the perimeter, projecting a stream of water inward at a 45° angle, rising {{convert|35|ft|m}}, driven by a {{convert|250|hp}} motor with a pump capacity of 6,750 [[Gallons per minute|GPM]] *The middle ring is {{convert|120|ft|m}} in diameter and consists of 18 nozzles directed vertically, rising to a height of {{convert|40|ft|m}}, driven by a {{convert|150|hp}} motor with a pump capacity of 4,500 GPM. *The center ring is {{convert|15|ft|m}} in diameter and contains nine nozzles operating vertically, rising to a height of {{convert|120|ft|m}}, driven by a {{convert|350|hp}} motor with a pump capacity of 5,500 GPM. * The fountain has an [[anemometer]] that controls the height of the center nozzles. If the force of the wind is from 5 to {{convert|15|mi|km}} an hour, the height of the center nozzles will not exceed {{convert|70|ft|m}}. For wind speed in excess of {{convert|15|mi|km}} an hour, the height of the center nozzles is limited to {{convert|50|ft|m}}. This was done to control the blow-off of water into the park and onto persons around the fountain. *Each nozzle has a cluster of four lights: dark red, light red, turquoise and amber.<ref>[http://www.metrojacksonville.com/content/view/200/5/ Metro Jacksonville website: Sep 11, 2006-Friendship Fountain: The Truth Beneath the Lies]</ref>
==Current status== [[Image:JaxFriendshipFountain2012.jpg|right|thumb|The fountain with path lighting and colored light towers around the fountain.]] [[File:Friendship Fountain and Jacksonville Landing at night.jpg|right|thumb|The fountain in 2018]] The future of the Jacksonville landmark was in doubt for a number of years. A number of proposals were made, including moving [[Kids Kampus]] from [[Metropolitan Park]] and eliminating the fountain, rebuilding a smaller fountain or renovating the existing fountain. As of May 2008, there was $15 million in the city's capital projects budget to improve the Southbank Riverwalk, which includes the area around Friendship Fountain; but Mayor [[John Peyton (U.S. politician)|John Peyton]] felt the amount was not enough.<ref>Littlepage, Ron: [http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/053008/opl_284245489.shtml "Let's upgrade riverwalk in time for 25th anniversary"] Florida Times-Union, May 30, 2008</ref>
The Jacksonville City Council approved final plans for a $3.2 million renovation and repair to the surrounding park and Friendship Fountain on February 9, 2010.<ref>Mitchell, Tia: [http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2010-02-09/story/jacksonville_council_oks_downtown_projects "Jacksonville council OKs downtown projects"] Florida Times-Union, February 9, 2010</ref> On August 10, 2010 [http://JaxFountain.com], The Friends of Friendship Fountain Website, reported communications from the Jacksonville Economic Development Commission that AC General Inc was named contractor for the project.<ref name="ldiline.com">[http://www.ldiline.com/home.cfm?id=16451 Friendship Fountain Park Renovations]</ref> An official groundbreaking was held on September 1, 2010 marking the start of the renovation of Friendship Fountain and Park.<ref>http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2010-09-01/story/friendship-fountain-fly-high-again-after-renovation-ground-breaking</ref><ref>http://www.actionnewsjax.com/content/actionlocal/story/Friendship-Fountain-restoration/IJ7w5R5_lU-kIQOkydwanQ.cspx</ref><ref>http://www.news4jax.com/news/24841680/detail.html</ref> The fountain was closed for eight months for construction, and reopened again on June 18, 2011 amid a celebration.<ref name="ldiline.com"/><ref>http://jacksonville.com/opinion/blog/403251/gary-mills/2011-06-18/flash-mob-celebrates-friendship-fountains-reopening</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = GAC Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Co., Ltd. | native_name = 广汽菲亚特汽车有限公司 | trading_name = GAC Fiat | logo = GAC Fiat logo.jpg | caption = | type = [[joint venture]] | traded_as = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|2010}} ([[Changsha]]) | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Changsha]] | location_country = China | location = | locations = | area_served = China | key_people = Zheng Xiancong
(President){{cite news|url=http://www.chinaautoreview.com/pub/CARArticle.aspx?ID=6413|title=GAC-Fiat: No plan to launch Chrysler brand any time soon|accessdate=13 April 2012|publisher=China Automotive Review|date=10 August 2011}}
Jack Cheng
(Managing Director){{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2010-09/27/content_11350708.htm|title=New venture formed for Fiat's second act|accessdate=13 April 2012|publisher=China Daily|date=27 September 2010}} | industry = [[Automotive industry|Automotive]] | products = [[Automobile]]s | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = [[GAC Group]] (50%)
{{nowrap|[[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]] (50%)}} | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.gacfiatauto.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} {{Chinese |t=廣汽菲亞特 |s=广汽菲亚特 |p=Guǎngqì Fēiyàtè |w= Kuang3-ch'i4 Fei1-ya4-t'e4 |mi={{IPAc-cmn|g|uang|3|q|i|4|-|f|ei|1|ya|4|t|e|4}} |order=st }} '''GAC Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Co., Ltd.''' is an automobile manufacturing company headquartered in [[Changsha]], [[China]] and a 50:50 [[joint-venture]] between [[GAC Group]] and [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]]. The company was founded on 9 March 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.gacfiatauto.com/website/recof/cominfo_jsp_catid_324_325_333.html|title=Company Profile|accessdate=13 April 2012|publisher=GAC Fiat Automobiles Co., Ltd.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322210940/http://www.gacfiatauto.com/website/recof/cominfo_jsp_catid_324_325_333.html|archivedate=22 March 2012|df=}} Fiat has agreed to invest an initial US$559 million in the venture.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/jul2009/gb2009077_696269.htm|title=Fiat Focuses on China|accessdate=13 April 2012|publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek|date=7 July 2009}} ==History== Fiat and GAC signed a joint venture agreement in Rome on 6 July 2009, in the presence of Chinese President Hu Jintao and Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. Construction of GAC Fiat facilities in Changsha began on 26 November 2009, with a groundbreaking ceremony attended by the Italian ambassador to China, the provincial leaders of Hunan and Guangdong, and city leaders of Changsha and Guangzhou.{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/bw/2009-11/30/content_9074421.htm|title=GAC-Fiat ceremony heralds joint venture|accessdate=13 April 2012|publisher=China Daily|date=30 November 2009}} GAC Fiat Automobiles Co., Ltd. was incorporated on 9 March 2010. The Changsha assembly plant was officially opened on 28 June 2012, in a ceremony attended by Fiat chief executive [[Sergio Marchionne]] and representatives of Hunan and Guandong provinces.{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Motoring/Story/STIStory_816528.html|title=Fiat opens new Chinese plant to produce Viaggio|accessdate=2 July 2012|publisher=Straits Times|date=28 June 2012}} In January 2013 it was announced that GAC Fiat would be expanded to also include Chrysler, and that GAC Fiat would construct a new assembly plant in Guangzhou for the production of [[Jeep]] products.{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20130116/AUTO04/301160335/1148/auto01/Fiat-Chrysler-Guangzhou-ink-Jeep-deal |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130215211655/http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20130116/AUTO04/301160335/1148/auto01/Fiat-Chrysler-Guangzhou-ink-Jeep-deal |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 February 2013 |title=Fiat-Chrysler, Guangzhou ink Jeep deal |accessdate=27 January 2013 |publisher=The Detroit News |date=16 January 2013 }}{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/01/13/us-fiat-chrysler-idINBRE90C06F20130113|title=Fiat, Chrysler to produce Jeep in China: paper|accessdate=27 January 2013|publisher=Reuters|date=14 January 2013}} The plant is planned to have an initial production capacity of 100,000 units per year.{{cite news|url=http://chinaautoweb.com/2013/01/gac-fiat-to-build-jeeps-in-guangzhou-next-gen-liberty-likely-to-be-the-first-model-to-roll-off-line/|title=GAC-Fiat to Build Jeeps in Guangzhou, Next-gen Liberty Likely to Be the First Model to Roll Off Line|accessdate=27 January 2013|publisher=China Auto Web|date=17 January 2013}} ==Operations== GAC Fiat has facilities in Changsha, with an annual production capacity of 140,000 cars and 220,000 engines, covering around 700,000 m2. Vehicle production begun in June 2012, with the [[Dodge Dart (2013)#Fiat Viaggio|Fiat Viaggio]] five-door sedan.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/04/13/uk-fiat-idUKBRE83C0F820120413|title=Fiat unveils new Viaggio model to be made and sold in China|accessdate=13 April 2012|publisher=Reuters|date=13 April 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://chinaautoweb.com/auto-companies/gac-fiat/ |title=GAC Fiat Chrysler|accessdate=3 July 2015|publisher=Chinaautoweb.com}} Later, the company started to manufacture the [[Fiat Ottimo|Ottimo]], ([[hatchback]] version of the Viaggio).{{cite news|url=http://europe.autonews.com/article/20141129/ANE/141129864/fiat-chrysler-deepens-china-partnership-to-help-jeep|title=Fiat Chrysler deepens China partnership to help Jeep|date=29 November 2014|accessdate=4 July 2015|work=Automotive News Europe |publisher=Crain Communications}} In October 2013, GAC Fiat announced the construction of a second manufacturing plant in Guangzhou due to be finalised in 2016.{{cite news|url=http://europe.autonews.com/article/20131029/ANE/131029878/fiats-china-jv-to-build-second-plant-to-produce-suvs-evs-report-says|title=Fiat's China JV to build second plant to produce SUVs, EVs, report says|date=29 October 2013|accessdate=4 July 2015|work=Automotive News Europe |publisher=Crain Communications}} In November 2014, Fiat Chrysler and GAC expanded their partnership to produce Jeep vehicles. ==Current production== *[[Jeep Cherokee (KL)|Jeep Cherokee (K4)]] 2015-present *[[Jeep Renegade (BU)|Jeep Renegade (BQ)]] 2016-present *[[Jeep_Compass#Second_generation_.28MP.3B_2017.E2.80.93present.29|Jeep Compass (M4)]] 2016-present *[[Jeep Grand Commander|Jeep Grand Commander (K8)]] (2018-present) ==Former production== *[[Dodge Dart (2013)#Fiat Viaggio|Fiat Viaggio]] June 2012-2017 *Fiat Ottimo 2014-2017 File:Fiat Viaggio 01 China 2013-03-03.jpg|A Fiat Viaggio File:Fiat Ottimo 2 China 2016-03-29.jpg|A Fiat Ottimo ==Sales figures== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Vehicle sales |- | 2012 | {{formatnum:11.288}}[http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/fiat/] |- | 2013 | {{formatnum:48.375}}[http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/fiat/] |- | 2014 | {{formatnum:68.090}}[http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/fiat/] |- | 2015 | {{formatnum:39.486}}[http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/fiat/][http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/jeep/] |- | 2016 | {{formatnum:145.708}}[http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/fiat/][http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/jeep/] |- | 2017 | {{formatnum:205.028}}[http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/fiat/][http://carsalesbase.com/china-car-sales-data/jeep/] |} ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== *[http://www.gacfiatauto.com/ GAC Fiat Official website] {{Fiat Group}} {{GAC Group}} {{Automotive industry in the People's Republic of China}} [[Category:Motor vehicle manufacturers of China]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Hunan]] [[Category:Companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Fiat]] [[Category:GAC Group joint ventures]] [[Category:Joint ventures]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2014}} '''Alexander George Downer''' (28 January 1839 – 17 August 1916), usually known as George, or A. G. Downer, was a prominent South Australian businessman and a partner with his brother Sir [[John Downer]] in the legal firm G & J Downer.<ref name=splendid>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article87312225 |title=A Splendid Citizen |newspaper=[[The Chronicle (Adelaide)|The Chronicle]] |location=Adelaide |date=19 August 1916 |accessdate=13 November 2012 |page=37 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==History== George Downer was born in [[Adelaide]], the eldest of four sons of [[Downer family|Henry Downer]], the others being Henry Edward Downer<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article162437526 |title=Death of Mr. H. E. Downer |newspaper=[[The Adelaide Observer]] |volume=LXII, |issue=3,332 |location=South Australia |date=12 August 1905 |accessdate=7 May 2018 |page=28 |via=National Library of Australia}} </ref> (22 March 1836 – 4 August 1905), John William Downer (1843–1915), <!--Frederick Field Downer (1846–1847)--> and Harold Field Downer<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46096004 |title=Death of Mr. Harold F. Downer |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=LII, |issue=12,644 |location=South Australia |date=24 May 1887 |accessdate=7 May 2018 |page=6 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> (1847 – 23 May 1887). He was educated at [[Francis Haire]]'s Academy and while quite young was articled to the firm of Bartley, Bakewell & Stow, whose principals included [[Randolph Isham Stow]]. He combined study of law, for which he had a ready talent, with journalism, and was for a time editor of the (Adelaide) ''Telegraph''. He was admitted to the bar in 1868. His brother John had only recently qualified and the two entered into partnership. The firm G & J Downer prospered and was eventually taken over by Frank H. and J. Fred Downer, sons of his brothers Henry Edward and John respectively.
His only attempt at a position in Parliament was in 1870 when he contested the seat of Gumeracha against [[Ebenezer Ward]] and [[Arthur Blyth]]. He was unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article60325086 |title=A Versatile Personality |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=9 October 1917 |accessdate=14 November 2012 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Around 1880 he was appointed by the government to a Pastoral Commission and was in a large part responsible for lengthening the tenure of leases of Crown lands.
Pastoralist [[Francis John Whitby]], a fellow student at Haire's Academy was a lifelong friend. Downer never married. After his death at his (c. 170) South Terrace residence, his Adelaide Hills property "Monalta" (previously known as "Hope Lodge")<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article57510354 |title=Missionary Students Migrating |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=7 May 1907 |accessdate=14 November 2012 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> near the [[Belair railway station]], was subdivided. The mansion eventually became [[Blackwood District Community Hospital]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48932986 |title=Out Among the People. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=18 November 1953 |accessdate=14 November 2012 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Sir John, his brother, had predeceased him on 2 August 1915 and his sister Amelia Rivaz had died on 21 July 1916.
==Business activities== He was much in demand for his business acumen as well as his knowledge of mercantile law. For around twenty years he was a *director of China Traders Company *trustee of [[Harrold Brothers]] *director, Norwich Union Assurance Company *director, [[Elder, Smith, & Co.]] from 1892<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48174231 |title=Elder,Smith & Co., Limited |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=1 September 1936 |accessdate=14 November 2012 |page=32 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> *director [[Bank of Adelaide]] from around 1894 and Chairman for most of that time He relinquished these positions in May 1914 as his health deteriorated. *He invested in a northern pastoral property which was resumed by the Government, then in 1888 a share of Minburra station and an adjoining property, making Melton Station, about 40 km from [[Yunta, South Australia|Yunta]].
== See also == *[[Downer family]]

The '''Golden Bull Award''' is a [[business award]] for [[Small and medium enterprises|SMEs]] in [[Malaysia]],<ref>{{cite news |title=SMEs elated to be among top 10 in Golden Bull Award |url=http://biz.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2007/7/23/business/20070723175412&sec=business |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |date=23 July 2007 |accessdate=5 May 2010 }}</ref> presented annually since 2003.<ref>{{cite news |title=Golden Bull Award returns |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-164360920.html |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=5 May 2010 }}</ref>
==Award Categories==
===Outstanding SMEs===
Criteria: SMEs with annual sales [[revenue|turnover]] of RM10 million and above up to RM75 million in the last three [[financial year]]s. For service and service related sectors, the maximum annual sales turnover is RM10 million in the last three financial years. No. of winners: 100
===Emerging SMEs=== Criteria: SMEs with annual sales turnover below RM5 million in the last three financial years. No. of winners: 20
===Golden Bull International Cooperation Honorary Award===
This award recognizes an [[international corporation]] for its collaboration with Malaysian SMEs in their growth and achievements, in particular the Golden Bull Award winners.
==Judging Criteria==
Evaluation of the companies' management and financial performance is done based on the following criteria:
*Management outlook *Vision and mission statements *Corporate uniqueness and philosophy *Projected plan to grow in the next 3 to 5 years *Major innovations *Market presence *[[Information technology]] usage *Operating profit before tax *Sales turnover *Profit growth over last three years *Turnover growth over last three years
All nominees will be judged by the following industry groupings and judging will be based on their performances within the grouping:
*[[Real estate]] and [[construction]] *[[Manufacturing]] *[[Trade|Trading]] *[[Telecommunications]] and [[Information and communication technologies|ICT]] *[[Service sector]] *Others
The final list of winning companies is judged and endorsed by an independent panel of industry leaders.
==Past winners== *2010 Emerging SME - [[Sri Guan Teik Enterprise Sdn Bhd]]<ref>http://www.goldenbullaward.com/2010/en/winner-list.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100220094342/http://www.goldenbullaward.com:80/ Official site]
[[Category:Business and industry awards]] [[Category:Economy of Malaysia]]

The '''Gulfstream Polo Club''' was a [[polo]] club in [[Lake Worth, Florida]]. Since 1923, Gulfstream Polo Club was one of the most prominent polo clubs in North America, particularly during the Florida season (December-April). Gulfstream was managed by Marla Connor for 18 years until it closed in May 2016 at the end of the polo season. Throughout its long history it offered a wide array of tournaments, with 4, 6, and 10 Goal Leagues as well as Ladies Tournaments.
==Location== It was located at 4550 Polo Road, Lake Worth, Florida, 33467, not far from the [[Museum of Polo and Hall of Fame]].<ref>[https://maps.google.co.uk/maps?hl=en&tab=wl Google Maps]</ref>
==History== It was started by the [[Phipps family]] North of [[Delray Beach, Florida]] in 1923, making it the oldest polo club in Florida.<ref name="ourhistory">[http://www.gulfstreampolo.com/history.htm Gulfstream Polo Club: Our History]</ref><ref name="history98">Horace A. Laffaye, ''Polo in the United States: A History'', Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland & Company, 2011, p. 98</ref><ref name="bill">Bill DiPaolo, [http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/local/polo-club-barn-catches-fire-in-wellington-putting-/nWmy3/ Seven horses die in barn fire at Gulfstream Polo Club; electrical overload in makeshift kitchen blamed], ''[[The Palm Beach Post]]'', March 9, 2013</ref> It became affiliated with the [[United States Polo Association]] in 1935.<ref name="history98"/>
In 1941, [[John H. H. Phipps]], [[Michael Grace Phipps]] (1910–1973), [[Charles Skiddy von Stade]] and [[Alan L. Corey, Jr.]], all players in residence at the Gulfstream Polo Club, won the [[U.S. Open Polo Championship]] at the [[Meadow Brook Polo Club]].<ref name="history98"/> However, during the [[Second World War]], the club was closed and the stables were used by US troops in case of an invasion.<ref name="ourhistory"/>
In the 1960s, the Phipps family sold the land in Delray Beach.<ref name="ourhistory"/> [[Philip L. B. Iglehart]] (1913-1993) together with [[Jim Kraml, Sr.]], [[Norberto Azqueta Sr.]], [[Robert Uihlein, Jr.]] (1916-1976), William Taylor, [[William Stamps Farish III]] (born 1939), [[James H. Binger]] (1916-2004), [[George C. Sherman, Jr.]] and [[Paul Butler (polo)|Paul Butler]] (1892-1981) purchased land in Lake Worth and re-established the polo club there.<ref name="ourhistory"/> There were five fields, including the Bostwick Field, named after [[Pete Bostwick]] (1909-1982), who was a club member.<ref name="ourhistory"/> [[Summerfield Johnston, Jr.]] served as a long-time club president.<ref>[http://www.polomuseum.com/hof_inductees/johnston_skey.htm Museum of Polo and Hall of Fame: S.K. (Skey) Johnston, Jr.]</ref>
It has been home to the USPA Delegate's Cup (8-Goal) since the mid-1970s, the USPA Bronze Cup (12-Goal) since the early 1980s, and the Heritage Cup (16-Goal) since 1987.<ref name="ourhistory"/>
The club closed permanently on May 20, 2016, following acquisition by Pulte Homes, a real estate development firm.<ref name="sunowershomesbuys">{{cite news|last1=Owers|first1=Paul|title=Pulte Homes buys Wellington polo club, horse farms|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/business/realestate/fl-pulte-wellington-20160504-story.html|accessdate=July 7, 2016|work=Sun Sentinel|date=May 4, 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Henry Ford II | image = Aankomst van Henry Ford II.ogv | caption = Henry Ford II arrives in the Netherlands (1954). | predecessor = [[Edsel Ford]] | office = [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the [[Ford Motor Company]] | successor = [[Philip Caldwell]] | term = 1945–1979 | birth_date = {{birth date|1917|09|04}} | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1987|09|29|1917|09|04}} | death_place = Detroit, Michigan, U.S. | occupation = Former Chairman and president and CEO of the [[Ford Motor Company]] | spouse = Anne McDonnell, 1940–1964 (divorced)
[[Cristina Ford|Maria Cristina Vettore]], 1965–1980 (divorced)
Kathleen DuRoss 1980–1987 (his death) | parents = [[Edsel Ford]]
[[Edsel Ford|Eleanor Clay Ford]] | relations = [[Henry Ford]] (grandfather)
[[William Clay Ford Sr.]] (brother)

[[Yale University]] }} [[File:MaxFisher.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Max Fisher (center), John Bugas (left), Henry Ford II (right) at Bugas's Wyoming ranch]]'''Henry Ford II''' (September 4, 1917 – September 29, 1987), sometimes known as "HF2" or "Hank the Deuce", was the eldest son of [[Edsel Ford]] and eldest grandson of [[Henry Ford]]. He was president of the [[Ford Motor Company]] from 1945 to 1960, [[chairman]] and [[Chief executive officer|chief executive officer (CEO)]] {{cite web |url=http://www.ford.com/en/heritage/fordFamily/default.htm |title=Henry Ford |accessdate=2007-02-14 |quote=Henry Ford resigned for the second time at the end of World War II. His eldest grandson, Henry Ford II, became president on Sept. 21, 1945. Even as Henry Ford II drove the industry's first postwar car off the assembly line, he was making plans to reorganize and decentralize the company to resume its prewar position as a major force in a fiercely competitive auto industry. Henry Ford II provided strong leadership for Ford Motor Company from the postwar era into the 1980s. He was president from 1945 until 1960 and chief executive officer from 1945 until 1979. He was chairman of the board of directors from 1960 until 1980, and remained as chairman of the finance committee from 1980 until his death in 1987. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213105146/http://www.ford.com/en/heritage/fordFamily/default.htm |archivedate=2007-02-13 |deadurl=yes}} and chairman for several months thereafter. Notably, under the leadership of Henry Ford II, Ford Motor Company became a publicly traded corporation in 1956. From 1943 to 1950, he also served as president of the [[Ford Foundation]]. ==Early life== Henry Ford II was born in [[Detroit]], Michigan, to [[Eleanor Clay Ford]] and [[Edsel Ford]] on September 4, 1917. He, brothers Benson and William, and sister Josephine, grew up amid affluence. He graduated from [[The Hotchkiss School]] in 1936.{{cite web |url=http://www.hotchkiss.org/alumni/Accomplishments.aspx |title=Alumni Award: PREVIOUS RECIPIENTS |publisher=The Hotchkiss School |date=2004 |accessdate=March 8, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310133421/http://www.hotchkiss.org/alumni/Accomplishments.aspx |archivedate=March 10, 2015 |df= }} He attended [[Yale University]], where he served on the business staff of ''[[The Yale Record]]'',Alexander, Cecil A. (May–June, 2004) "The Pranks of Yesteryear". ''The Harvard Magazine''. Cambridge: Harvard. the campus humor magazine, but left in 1940 before graduation.{{cite web| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-09-30/news/mn-7220_1_henry-ford-ii| title= Henry Ford II Dies; Led Auto Firm 35 Years| last=Thackery, Jr.| first=Ted| work=[[Los Angeles Times]]| accessdate=July 26, 2015}} ==Career== When his father [[Edsel Ford|Edsel]], president of Ford, died of cancer in May 1943 (during [[World War II]]), Henry Ford II was serving in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] and unable to take over the presidency of the family-owned business. The elderly and ailing [[Henry Ford]], company founder, re-assumed the presidency. By this point in his life, the elder Ford was mentally inconsistent, suspicious, and no longer fit for the job; most of the directors did not want to see him as president. But for the previous 20 years, although he had long been without any official executive title, he had always had de facto control over the company; the board and the management had never seriously defied him, and this moment was not different. The directors elected him, and he served until the end of the war.{{Harvnb|Sorensen|1956|pp=325–326}} During this period the company began to decline, losing over $10 million a month. The administration of President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] considered a government takeover of the company in order to ensure continued war production, but the idea never progressed to execution. Henry Ford II left the Navy in July 1943 and joined the company's management a few weeks later. After two years, he assumed presidency of the business on September 21, 1945. Since it had been assumed that Edsel Ford would continue in his capacity as president of the company for much longer than turned out to be the case, Henry Ford II had received little grooming for the position, and he took over the company during a chaotic period; its European factories had suffered a great deal of damage during the war, and domestic sales were also in decline. Henry Ford II immediately adopted an aggressive management style. One of his first acts as company president was to place [[John Bugas]] in charge of taking control of the company from its entrenched management and firing [[Harry Bennett]], head of the Ford Service Department, whom his grandfather initially hired to stifle attempts at [[unionization]]. Next, acknowledging his inexperience, he hired several seasoned executives to support him. He hired former [[General Motors Corporation|General Motors]] executives [[Ernest Breech]] and Lewis Crusoe away from the [[Bendix Corporation]]. Breech was to serve in the coming years as HF2's business mentor, and the Breech–Crusoe team would form the core of Ford's business expertise, offering much-needed experience. Additionally, Henry Ford II hired ten young up-and-comers, known as the "[[Whiz Kids (Ford)|Whiz Kids]]". These ten, gleaned from an [[Army Air Forces]] statistical team, Henry Ford II envisioned as giving the company the ability to innovate and stay current. Two of them, Arjay Miller and [[Robert McNamara]], went on to serve as presidents of Ford themselves. A third member, [[J. Edward Lundy]], served in key financial roles for several decades and helped to establish Ford Finance's reputation as one of the best Finance organizations in the world. As a team, the "whiz kids" are probably best remembered as the design team for the [[1949 Ford]], which they took from concept to production in nineteen months, and which re-established Ford as a formidable automotive company. It was reported that 100,000 orders for this car were taken the day it was introduced to the market. Henry Ford II was president of [[Ford Motor Company]] from 1945 to 1960. In 1956, under his leadership, the company became a publicly traded corporation and dedicated its new [[Ford World Headquarters|world headquarters building]]. When he resigned the presidency, he became CEO of the company. During his term as CEO of Ford, he resided in [[Grosse Pointe]], [[Michigan]]. On July 13, 1960, he was additionally elected Chairman; he resigned as CEO on October 1, 1979, and as Chairman in 1980. His nephew, [[William Clay Ford, Jr.]] would later assume these positions after 20 years of non-Ford family management of the company. During the interim, the family interests were represented on the board by Henry's younger brother [[William Clay Ford, Sr.]], as well as Henry's son [[Edsel Ford II]] and his nephew William Clay Ford, Jr. During the early 1960s Henry Ford II engaged in lengthy negotiations with [[Enzo Ferrari]] to buy [[Ferrari]], with a view to expanding Ford's presence in motorsport in general and at the [[Le Mans 24 Hours]] in particular. However negotiations collapsed due to disputes over control over Ferrari's [[Scuderia Ferrari|racing division]]. The collapse of the deal led him to inaugurate the [[Ford GT40]] project, intended to end Ferrari's dominance at Le Mans (the Italian marque won the race six consecutive times from 1960 to 1965). After two difficult years in 1964 and 1965, in 1966 GT40s locked out the podium at both the [[Daytona 24 Hours]] and the [[1966 12 Hours of Sebring|Sebring 12 Hours]] before taking the first of four consecutive wins at [[1966 24 Hours of Le Mans|Le Mans]].{{cite web |url=http://www.redbull.com/uk/en/motorsports/stories/1331777719573/ford-gt40-heroes-of-motorsport |title=Legends: Ford GT40 |last1=Stuart |first1=Greg |date=19 February 2016 |website=[[Red Bull]]|access-date=19 June 2016}} In 1973 and 1974, as it became clear that the American car market would begin to favor smaller, more fuel-efficient cars, [[Ford]]'s then-President [[Lee Iacocca]] was highly interested in buying [[powertrain]]s from [[Honda Motor Company]] as a way to minimize the cost of developing a small Ford car for the North American market, such as a modified version of [[Ford of Europe]]'s [[Ford Fiesta]]. The plan was rejected by Henry Ford II, who stated: "No car with my name on the hood is going to have a Jap engine inside." Although, strictly speaking, it was too late for that, as the Ford Motor Company had been selling a Mazda compact pickup truck as the Ford Courier since late 1971, Henry Ford II did not like the idea of flagship North American passenger car models moving in that direction. Ford Motor Company did go on to adapt to the era in which Japanese, German, and American participation in a globalized automobile industry became tightly integrated. For example, Ford's relationship with [[Mazda]] was well developed even before the end of HF2's period of influence. However, in Iacocca's view, it lagged several years behind GM and Chrysler, due to Henry Ford II's unappealable influence, before others led it forward despite his resistance. HF2's management style caused the company's fortunes to fluctuate in more ways than one. For example, he allowed the offering of [[public stock]] in 1956, which raised $650 million for the company, but the "experimental car" program instituted during his tenure, the [[Edsel]], cost the company almost half that. Likewise, HF2 hired the creative [[Lee Iacocca]], who was fundamental to the success of the [[Ford Mustang]], in 1964, but fired Iacocca due to personal disputes in 1978 (about the break in their relationship, Iacocca quoted Ford as saying, "Sometimes you just don't like somebody"). He formally retired from all positions at Ford Motor Company on October 1, 1982, upon reaching the company's mandatory retirement age of 65, but remained the ultimate source of authority at Ford until his death in 1987. ==Awards and achievements== * 1969, awarded the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] from President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] * 1983, inducted into the [[Automotive Hall of Fame]] ==Personal life== Henry Ford II was married three times: * Anne McDonnell (1919Social Security Death Index; Ford: The Men and the Machine (Little, Brown & Co., pub.), c. 1986 by Robert Lacey, First Edition; New York State Census, 1925; Edsel & Eleanor Ford House (Guide-books, by James A. Bridenstine, Genealogy, p. 101, chart) - 1996), a daughter of [[James Francis McDonnell]].{{cite book| title=Ford: The Men and the Machine| publisher=Little, Brown & Co.| year=1986| first=Robert| last=Lacey| edition=First| page=101| isbn=9780316511667}} They married in 1940 and divorced in 1964 (she married Deane F. Johnson in 1968). The Fords had three children: **Charlotte Ford **Anne Ford **[[Edsel Ford II]]{{cite news| title=Anne Ford Johnson, 76, Dies; Influenced Fashion and Arts| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/nyregion/anne-ford-johnson-76-dies-influenced-fashion-and-arts.html| last=Nemy| first=Enid| date=March 31, 1996| work=[[The New York Times]]}} * [[Cristina Ford|Maria Cristina Vettore]] (1929 - 2008), formerly wife of Robin Willoughby Merivale Austin, a Canadian in the British Royal Navy; married 1946,Andrews Newspaper Index Cards, 1790-1976, England divorced 1950 - 1959; she and Ford married in New York, New York in 1965 and divorced in 1980.{{cite book| title=Edsel & Eleanor Ford House| first=James A.| last=Bridenstine| page=101| date=February 1989| publisher=Wayne State University Press}} * Kathleen DuRoss (born Kathleen Roberta King, 1940), widow of L. David DuRoss1940 U.S. Federal Census (died 1959);Ancestry.com, Public Member Trees (Provo, Utah, U.S.A., Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2006), www.ancestry.com, Database online, records for L. David DuRoss she and Ford were married in Carson City, Nevada, 1980. By this marriage, Ford had two stepdaughters: **Deborah Guibord ([[née]] DuRoss) **Kimberly DuRoss Ford died of [[pneumonia]] in Detroit at [[Henry Ford Hospital]] on September 29, 1987, at age 70. After a private funeral service at [[Christ Church Grosse Pointe]], his remains were cremated and the ashes scattered.{{cite news| title=100 Close Relatives, Friends at Rites for Henry Ford II| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-10-02/news/mn-7753_1_edsel-ii| date=October 2, 1987| work=Los Angeles Times| agency=[[United Press International]]| accessdate=2017-08-09}} ==Filmography== *''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' (1965) - Extra at the Nassau Casino (uncredited) ==See also== {{wikiquote}} * [[Ford family tree]] * [[Henry Ford II High School]] * [[Ford Foundation]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *Brinkley, Douglas. (2003) Wheels for the World: Henry Ford, His Company, and a Century of Progress. New York: Viking Press. * Lacey, Robert. (1986) Ford: The Men and the Machine. Boston: Little, Brown. * Nevins, Allan and Frank Ernest Hill (1962) Ford: Decline and Rebirth 1933-1962. New York: Scribners. * {{Sorensen1956}} ==External links== * {{Find a Grave|8514154}} * {{Internet Archive film clip|id=gov.archives.arc.95999|description="Longines Chronoscope with Henry II Ford (SIC)"}} * {{PM20|FID=pe/005384}} {{s-start}} {{s-bus}} {{s-bef|before=[[Henry Ford]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Chief Executive Officer]] of the [[Ford Motor Company]]|years=1945–1979}} {{s-aft|after=[[Philip Caldwell]]}} {{s-end}} {{Henry Ford}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ford, Henry II}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Detroit]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Ford executives]] [[Category:Henry Ford family]] [[Category:Hotchkiss School alumni]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in Michigan]] [[Category:Military personnel from Michigan]] [[Category:Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients]] [[Category:Commanders Crosses of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]]

{{Infobox person | name = Henry Phipps Jr. | image = Henry Phipps 1913.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Phipps in 1913 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1839|9|27}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = {{nowrap|{{death date and age|1930|9|22|1839|9|27}}}} | death_place = [[Great Neck, New York|Great Neck]], [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Co-founder of [[Carnegie Steel Company|Carnegie Steel]], philanthropy | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | occupation = | home_town = | title = | salary = | net_worth = USD $60 million at the time of his death (approximately 1/1,506th of US [[Gross national product|GNP]]){{Citation | last=Klepper | first=Michael | last2=Gunther | first2=Michael | publication-date=1996 | title=The Wealthy 100: From Benjamin Franklin to Bill Gates—A Ranking of the Richest Americans, Past and Present | publisher=Carol Publishing Group | publication-place=[[Secaucus, New Jersey]] | page=xiii | isbn=978-0-8065-1800-8 | oclc=33818143}} | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = Carnegie Steel Co.
[[United States Steel Corporation|United States Steel Corp.]] | spouse = {{marriage|Anne Childs Shaffer|1872}} | partner = | children = 5 | parents = | family = [[Phipps family|Phipps]] | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Henry Phipps Jr.''' (September 27, 1839 – September 22, 1930) was an [[United States|American]] [[entrepreneur]] known for his business relationship with [[Andrew Carnegie]] and involvement with the [[Carnegie Steel Company]]. He was also a successful [[real estate]] investor. After selling his stock in Carnegie Steel, he devoted a great deal of his time and money to [[philanthropist|philanthropic]] works. ==Early life== Henry Phipps Jr. was born on September 27, 1839 in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. He was the son of English born Hannah Frank and Henry Phipps, an [[England|English]] [[shoemaker]] who migrated to Philadelphia in the early part of the 19th century before settling in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]] in 1845.{{cite news|title=Phipps|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/146221940/|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The Pittsburgh Press|date=July 24, 1987}} He was educated at public schools in [[Allegheny City, Pennsylvania]]. He had one sister, Amelia Phipps Walker (Mrs. John Walker; 1846-1887), and two brothers: William Henry Phipps (1825-1902), and John Phipps (1833-1860), who was also friends with Carnegie and who died young.{{cite book|last1=Bridge|first1=James Howard|title=The Inside History of the Carnegie Steel Company: A Romance of Millions|date=August 21, 2014|publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press|location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|isbn=9780822990574|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jeNnRRSqFEMC&pg=PA348&dq=carnegie+steel+henry+phipps&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjw7s7NxPbOAhXFkx4KHVBIA2gQ6AEILTAD#v=onepage&q=henry%20phipps&f=false|accessdate=4 September 2016|language=en}} ==Career== Phipps began working as a young man as an office boy and later a bookkeeper with Dillworth & Bidwell. In 1861, he became a partner in Bidwell & Phipps, which was an agent for the [[DuPont|du Pont Powder Company]], and a partner in Kloman & Phipps, a small [[iron mill]]. ===Involvement with Carnegie=== In 1865, he became a partner in childhood friend and neighbor's [[Andrew Carnegie|Andrew]] (1835–1919) and [[Thomas M. Carnegie|Thomas Carnegie]]'s (1843–1886) [[Thomas M. Carnegie#Union Iron Mills|Union Iron Mills]],{{cite news|last1=Train|first1=John|title=REJUVENATING OLD MONEY|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1986/06/08/066886.html?pageNumber=629|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=June 8, 1986}} which was created from a merger between Phipps' Kloman & Phipps and Cyclops Iron Company, an iron company which the Carnegies had acquired an interest in.{{cite news|author=Griffiths, William|title=Henry Phipps--The Man and His Millions|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/04/02/119116891.html?pageNumber=40|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=April 2, 1905}} Kloman and Phipps at first refused, but Thomas made an offer of all the shares in Cyclops plus an additional payment of $50,000 ({{Inflation|US|50000|1865|r=-3|fmt=eq}}).Bridge, 1903, p. 23. Therefore, on May 1, 1865, the new Union Iron Mills Company was formed.Derbyshire, 2008, p. 78-79. For the next year, Phipps and Carnegie went to Europe on tour, and when they returned in 1866, went to work. Phipps toiled for the next 20 years and proved a capable financier, becoming Carnegie's business partner in [[Carnegie Steel Company]], founded in 1892, which would make him a very wealthy man as the company's second largest shareholder. In 1901, Carnegie Steel Company was sold to the [[United States Steel Corporation]]; a newly formed organisation, set up by [[Pierpont Morgan]].Nasaw, D., 2006, p.580-588 It sold for $400 million (approx. $13.3 billion today), of which $226 million went to Carnegie himself,Nasaw, D., 2006, p.687 and $48 million went to Phipps. In 1907, Henry Phipps established [[Bessemer Trust|Bessemer Trust Company]] to manage his substantial assets that would be shared by his offspring following his death. ===Real estate=== In 1909, Phipps expanded his Cape Cod holdings to the entire 800 acre Great Island on [[Cape Cod]], purchasing the remaining 50 acres from [[Charles B. Cory]] (1857–1921).{{cite news|title=PHIPPS OWNS GREAT ISLAND. Now in Full Possession of Cape Cod Estate of 800 Acres.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/01/19/101861803.html?pageNumber=1|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 19, 1909}} The Cape Cod estate was next to Aberdeen Hall{{cite book|title=Country Life, Volume 13|date=April 1908|publisher=Doubleday, Page, & Company|page=567|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhoiAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA567&lpg=PA567&dq=great+island+cape+cod+henry+phipps&source=bl&ots=S7aEV0lWYx&sig=QTo8xEeZJGMImEBWegb4fWq-9_w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjY78Gdn_bOAhVGWx4KHVntAQwQ6AEINDAE#v=onepage&q=great%20island%20cape%20cod%20henry%20phipps&f=false|accessdate=4 September 2016|language=en}} (which burnt down in September 1924{{cite news|last1=Zindler|first1=Ethan|title=Battling the winds of time|url=http://www.capecodtimes.com/article/20050522/BIZ/305229995|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[Cape Cod Times]]|date=May 22, 2005}}) and was near Andrew Carnegie, [[Henry M. Flagler]], and [[Henry Clay Frick]]'s estates.{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Wendy|last2=Whitcomb|first2=Robert|title=Cape Wind: Money, Celebrity, Class, Politics, and the Battle for Our Energy Future|date=2009|isbn=9781458719447|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mNXZSizBEoYC&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=great+island+cape+cod+henry+phipps&source=bl&ots=hJxMR_1c7f&sig=OE6G6SC9QaUc923QEdYCn6rmmEA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjY78Gdn_bOAhVGWx4KHVntAQwQ6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=phipps&f=false|accessdate=4 September 2016|language=en}} In 1912, Phipps divided $3,000,000 ({{Inflation|US|3000000|1912|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) worth of real estate in Chicago, Illinois realty among his three sons.{{cite news|title=PHIPPS GIVES SONS $3,000,000 Transfers Chicago Real Estate to Them — Tired of Managing It.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/02/25/100353090.html?pageNumber=1|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 25, 1912}} Later in the same year, he also gave his sons $10,000,000 ({{Inflation|US|10000000|1912|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) worth of property in Pittsbugh.{{cite news|title=PHIPPS BUYS AT PALM BEACH, New Yorker Will Build Three Villas There for His Family.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/03/28/104847211.html?pageNumber=11|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 28, 1912}} In 1916, he purchased property in [[Great Neck, Long Island]] in the [[Lake Success, New York|Village of Lake Success]] and in 1917, began construction on a thirty-nine-room Georgian mansion summer home, which was completed in 1919. He named the home, Bonnie Blink, which is Scottish for Pretty View. After his death, the mansion and property were donated to the school district and have since become [[William A. Shine Great Neck South High School]]."Lucky 7", (''Match, Richard'')."This is Great Neck", (''The League of Women Voters of Great Neck''). In 1926, he bought Island Beach, which was sold by his heirs in 1953 to the [[New Jersey|State of New Jersey]]. Now known as [[Island Beach State Park]], it is the last remaining stretch of undeveloped barrier island on the central New Jersey coast.{{cite news|title=BEACHLAND IN NEW JERSEY ASKED AS NATIONAL PARK|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1950/07/17/91108498.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA®ion=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=23|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=July 17, 1950}} Phipps was one of the pioneer investors in [[Florida]] real estate. At one time, he and his family owned one-third of the town of [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]], 28 miles (approximately 45 kilometers) of oceanfront between Palm Beach and [[Fort Lauderdale]], prime bay front property in downtown [[Miami]], and 29,653 acres (approximately 12,000 hectares) of land in [[Martin County, Florida|Martin County]]. The Phipps family donated to the town of Palm Beach one of the most significant gifts in county history: an ocean-to-lake frontage property that is now known as [[Elinor Klapp-Phipps Park|Phipps Park]]. ===Philanthropy=== [[File:Phipps Houses d jeh.jpg|thumb|left|Phipps Houses, Queens, NYC]] Phipps believed that those who have achieved great wealth should give back for the public good and create institutions dedicated to that purpose.The Philanthropy Hall of Fame, [http://www.philanthropyroundtable.org/almanac/hall_of_fame/henry_phipps_jr Henry Phipps Jr.] As such he was involved with a number of philanthropic causes, the best known of which is the [[Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens]] in [[Schenley Park]], an 1893 gift to the city of Pittsburgh. Among his many benevolent works, he also funded the [[Phipps Institute for the Study, Treatment and Prevention of Tuberculosis]]{{cite news|title=HENRY PHIPPS INSTITUTE Will Be Established for Treatment of Tuberculosis. One-Time Partner of Mr. Carnegie Gives $1,000,000 for the Purpose — Will Be Located in Philadelphia.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1903/01/10/101965054.html?pageNumber=1|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 10, 1903}} at the [[University of Pennsylvania]]{{cite news|title=Phipps Family Makes $500,000 Gift.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/04/11/112651316.html?pageNumber=23|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 11, 1920}} and [[The Henry Phipps Psychiatric Clinic]] at [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]]{{cite news|title=GAVE COLLEGE $1,000,000. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Phipps Donated Sum to Johns Hopkins.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/02/23/301961752.html?pageNumber=14|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 23, 1924}} which in 1913 made possible the first inpatient facility in the United States for the [[mentally ill]] constructed as part of an acute care hospital. Phipps was also an advocate of decent housing for the poor and in 1905 Phipps funded the non-profit Phipps Houses to build affordable housing in [[New York City]].{{cite news|title=PHIPPS HOUSES CHARTERED. Incorporation Bill Signed to Aid Philanthropic Dwelling Plans.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/04/23/101324782.html?pageNumber=3|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=April 23, 1905}}[http://www.phippsny.org/about.html Community Development | PCDC | About] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929120112/http://www.phippsny.org/about.html |date=2011-09-29 }}. www.phippsny.org He gave $1,000,000 ({{Inflation|US|1000000|1904|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) to build tenement houses for "working people."{{cite news|title=PHIPPS GIVES MILLION FOR MODEL TENEMENTS Former Associate of Carnegie Outlines His Plan. CHOOSES BOARD OF TRUSTEES Will Probably Build on Upper East Side—Playgrounds for Children Profits to Extend Work.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/01/14/101318593.html?pageNumber=1|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=January 14, 1905}} Phipps Houses still operates to this day; Henry Phipps's great-grandson, [[Stuart S. Janney III]], sits on its Board of Trustees. ==Personal life== [[File:Mrs Henry Phipps and Her Grandson Winston John Singer Sargent 1907.jpeg|thumb|240px|''Mrs Henry Phipps and Her Grandson Winston'', oil on canvas, [[John Singer Sargent]], 1907]]In 1872, Henry Phipps married Anne Childs Shaffer (1850–1934),{{cite news|title=MRS. HENRY PHIPPS BURIED Service Held at Westbury for Widow of Philanthropist.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1934/10/27/98538283.html?pageNumber=15|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=October 27, 1934}} the daughter of Margaret and John Shaffer, a Pittsburgh wagon builder. Since their estate Bonnie Brink was completed in 1919, they spent their summers in [[Great Neck, Long Island]]. The couple had two daughters and three sons: * [[Frederick Guest#Family and private life|Amy Phipps]] (1872–1959), who in 1905 married [[Frederick Edward Guest]] (1875–1937), the grandson of [[John Spencer-Churchill, 7th Duke of Marlborough]] and [[Winston Churchill]]'s first cousin. * [[John Shaffer Phipps]] (1874–1958), who in 1903 married Margarita Celia Grace, daughter of [[Michael P. Grace]] (1842–1920).{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E0DB1039E333A25756C0A9679D946297D6CF | work=The New York Times | title=Phipps--Grace.; Mendels--Wright. Hirsch-Dittenhoefer. Wright--Finck | date=November 5, 1903}} * Helen Margaret Phipps (1876–1934), who in 1904 married [[Bradley-Martin Ball|Bradley Martin]] in [[Scotland]],{{cite news|title=MARTIN-PHIPPS WEDDING. Daughter of Henry Phipps Married to Bradley Martin, Jr.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/11/03/120272540.html?pageNumber=9|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=November 3, 1904}} brother-in-law of [[William Craven, 4th Earl of Craven]] (1868–1921).{{cite news|title=DEATH TAKES WIFE OF BRADLEY MARTIN {{!}} New York Society Woman Is Victim of Appendicitis in Pasadena, Calif. {{!}} HENRY PHIPPS'S DAUGHTER {{!}} Father, Partner of Carnegie in Pioneer Steel Era, Gave Many. Millions to Charity.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1934/03/17/95479659.html?pageNumber=15|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=March 17, 1934}} * [[Henry Carnegie Phipps]] (1879–1953), who in 1907 married [[Gladys Mills Phipps|Gladys Livingston Mills]] (1883–1970).{{cite news|title=GLADYS MILLS WEDS HENRY C. PHIPPS Special Train Carries New York Guests to Staatsburg for Brilliant Ceremony GIFTS VALUED AT $2,000,000 Bride's Father-in-Law Presents Her with House in East 85th Street — Viilagers Entertained.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/12/08/104712432.html?pageNumber=11|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 8, 1907}} * Howard Phipps (1881–1981), who in 1931 married Harriet Dyer Price, daughter of Theodore Hazeltine Price and granddaughter of [[Alexander Brydie Dyer|Alexander B. Dyer]] (1815–1874).{{cite news|title=MISS PRICE BRIDE OF HOWARD PHIPPS {{!}} Ceremony at Her Parents' Park Avenue Home Performed by Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland. {{!}} NO BRIDAL ATTENDANTS {{!}} Marriage Unites Prominent Families—Mr. Phipps Is Son of Late Noted Philanthropist.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1931/10/23/112693422.html?pageNumber=27|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=October 23, 1931}} Phipps died in [[Great Neck, New York]] on September 22, 1930,{{cite news |author= |title=Henry Phipps Dead. Pioneer In Steel. Former Partner Of Carnegie, Who Amassed $100,000,000, Succumbs At 90. Gave $7,000,000 To Charity. Began Career As Messenger Boy. Divided Much Of Estate Among Three Sons In 1912. Gave More Than $7,000,000 To Charity. An Office Boy With Carnegie. Built Fifth Avenue Mansion. Financed Model Tenements |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0913FB3B5C11738DDDAA0A94D1405B808FF1D3 |quote=Henry Phipps, capitalist and philanthropist, who rose from office boy to master of a $100,000,000 fortune, died yesterday at his estate, Bonnie Brink, in the Lakeville section of Great Neck, L.I., at the age of 90. On Saturday he would have been 91 years old. Mr. Phipps had retired ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=September 23, 1930 |accessdate=2010-03-29 }} and his wife, Anne died in October 1934. At his death, Phipps' estate was worth $3,121,810.32 ({{Inflation|US|3121810|1930|r=-3|fmt=eq}}), according to transfer tax appraisal documents,{{cite news|title=Phipps's Estate $3,121,810|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1932/11/13/100873370.html?pageNumber=8|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=November 13, 1932}} of which $2,212,002 ({{Inflation|US|2212002|1930|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) was in stocks and bonds, $926,679 ({{Inflation|US|926679|1930|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) was in properties, notes, cash and insurance bonds, and $375 in jointly owned property. His wife was the sole beneficiary of his estate according to his June 1, 1915 will. ==See also== * [[Phipps family]] * [[Phipps-McElveen Building]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|3}} ;Sources *Bridge, James Howard. ''The Inside History of the Carnegie Steel Company: A Romance of Millions.'' New York: The Aldine Book Company, 1903. *Derbyshire, Wyn. ''Six Tycoons: The Lives of John Jacob Astor, Cornelius Vanderbilt, Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller, Henry Ford and Joseph P. Kennedy.'' London: Spiramus Press, 2008. *Nasaw, David. ''Andrew Carnegie.'' New York: Penguin Press, 2006. ==Further reading== {{Commons category|Henry Phipps}} * [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A00E5D7163BF930A15752C1A9659C8B63 November 23, 2003 ''New York Times'' article titled "''Streetscapes/Henry Phipps and Phipps Houses; Millionaire's Effort to Improve Housing for the Poor''"] * ''Halcyon Days: An American Family Through Three Generations'' by Peggie Phipps Boegner (daughter of [[John Shaffer Phipps]]), Richard Gachot (1987) [[Harry N. Abrams, Inc.]] {{ISBN|0-8109-1064-0}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Phipps, Henry}} [[Category:American manufacturing businesspeople]] [[Category:American steel industry businesspeople]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:1839 births]] [[Category:1930 deaths]] [[Category:Phipps family|*]] [[Category:American corporate directors]] [[Category:Philanthropists from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Pittsburgh]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:Andrew Carnegie]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]]

revision.text:
The '''Investor Relations Society''' (IR Society) is the professional body for [[investor relations]] professionals in the [[United Kingdom]].
Established in 1980, The Investor Relations Society is a non-profit making institute and has almost 600 members drawn primarily from UK listed companies, as well as overseas companies operating in the UK. Its UK members represent two-thirds of companies listed on the FTSE 100 Index.
Investor Relations activities in the UK are covered by a number of legal and regulatory requirements including the [[Companies Act 2006]], [[Financial Services and Markets Act 2000]] and The Criminal Justice Act 1993. The [[Financial Services Authority]] in the UK also publishes indications of best practice. The Investor Relations Society runs educational programmes to assist with the understanding of the legal and regulatory framework in the UK.
The Investor Relations Society has counterparts in many other countries including the United States, Australia and The Netherlands.
==External links== * [http://www.irs.org.uk/index.asp?pageid=1 The Investor Relations Society] Official site.
==References== *[http://www.ethicalcorp.com/content.asp?ContentID=532 Ethical Corporation: 19 Apr 2003: UK Investor relations society takes issue with CSR ‘lobbyists’] *[http://www.manifest.co.uk/manifest-i/fact_boxes/0202IRSfact_box.htm Manifest Information Services Limited - The Investor Relations Society (IRS)] *[http://www.aira.org.au/IRM/content/aboutus_related.html Australasian Investor Relations Association (AIRA)] *[http://www.niri.org National Investor Relations Institute, United States] *[http://www.iirf.org/about/MemberSocieties.aspx International Investor Relations Federation]
[[Category:Organizations established in 1980]] [[Category:Business organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1980 establishments in the United Kingdom]]
{{UK-org-stub}}
